Mr. President, first of all, congratulations to the rapporteur, Ms. De Sarnecca, who has done an excellent job of synthesis, especially in a context where the Commission and, even more so, the Council have not always shown great openness to the requests of this Parliament.
The development committee approved my report unanimously; some of our concerns were addressed, while we remain quite dissatisfied with other points.

However, we take a step back, with a sense of responsibility, considering it crucial to obtain approval of the entire package at first reading, thus ensuring that the process can begin on the scheduled date of January 1st.
Excellent to have quadrupled the funds for students, but beware: a significant portion comes from resources allocated to DCI and Cotonou development.
We will therefore be vigilant in demanding strict adherence to the overall regulatory framework, especially with regard to the DCI.

For now, I send my sincere best wishes to the many European youth from all corners of the world who, with a spirit of friendship, sharing, a desire to learn and grow, will be the protagonists of this extraordinary experience.
- There's one more thing. - Congratulations to the speaker, indeed.
As a member of the petitions committee, based on the data in the report and also on my personal experience, I would like to offer both a word of thanks and an invitation.

A thank you is in order, as the progress compared to the previous year is evident. We have gone from 449 to 518 eligible applications, from 12% to 16% of the total, with an increase also in the investigations carried forward.
I believe, therefore, that the path we have taken is a good one.
However, and this is the invitation, efforts in terms of communication must still be increased.

Let us study effective methods together, perhaps starting from our schools, to ensure that citizens receive high-quality information about the role, functions, and competencies of the European Ombudsman.
There are interesting projects in this regard that launched this year and need to be implemented and supported.
In this way, the already good numbers today will certainly continue to improve.
Mr. President, Ms. Commissioner, esteemed colleagues, our primary goal is to ensure that Europe has a common agricultural policy even after 2013.

We believe that this is fundamental not only for safeguarding the agricultural sector and the socioeconomic fabric in member countries, but also because, at the dawn of the third millennium, it is more strategically necessary than ever to ensure Europe's food security.

Madam Commissioner, we wish to emphasize that it is necessary to continue implementing support policies for individual CMO where required, and in particular, we believe that in the tobacco sector, the decoupling of aid should provide for the possibility of an increase in resources.

We must maintain a partial coupled aid until 2013 in order to prevent the total abandonment of production, as this would put entire supply chains at risk, creating unemployment as well as various economic and environmental problems in particularly disadvantaged areas.
I would like to remind you, Commissioner and President, that the European Parliament has already expressed its support for this issue by a large majority.

In the dairy sector, in order to rebalance the market in the short term and to allow for a smooth exit from the quota system in the long term, it would be appropriate to increase quotas by 2% for each marketing year from 2009 to 2014.
Madam Commissioner, honorable colleagues, I am very pleased to take as a very positive indication of your work capacity.
co-decision-making in agricultural matters, which was achieved through enhanced cooperation between the Council, the Commission, and the European Parliament.
It is a good omen, and it will also allow me, of course, to congratulate Mr. Capolas Santos on his balanced report.
report on modulation, young farmers, workplace safety, as well as in the face of new challenges.

We are going through a challenging transition, one that involves destination and decoupling, as well as other innovative measures. It is crucial that we protect struggling breeders during this transition.
We must take advantage of this opportunity to initiate a serious and in-depth reflection on the issue of tobacco, which is a staple product for agriculture and production.
after 2013 to update the objectives and new missions of the CAP and to begin discussing the overcoming of the dichotomy between the first and second pillars.

Mr. President, I appreciate the great efforts of our rapporteur, Capolas Santos, to keep the CAP closer to farmers and European citizens rather than market demands, and to reconcile the various concerns in the face of the many challenges at stake.
Therefore, a common approach by the 27 States in this sector is indispensable, but it is important to maintain support and market management tools for the main productions.

I think, for example, of the home textile sector or tobacco subsidies. Their abolition would certainly not contribute to reducing smoking, but rather to the elimination of an important European production and the social fabric associated with it.
Such tools must, however, always take into account the extremely diverse reality of the European landscape.
The currently valid dairy quota system, for example, is based on now-obsolete criteria.
The 1% increase proposed in the compromise is insufficient to meet the internal demand of many Member States.

What is needed, therefore, is a more flexible system that gives each individual Member State the possibility to respond to its own needs, which would also enhance the European competitiveness of the sector in the international market.
Mr. President, our group is quite satisfied with these two proposals.

This is adequately, though not entirely, demonstrated by the number of amendments in which we have attempted to contribute to the improvement of these texts, and we are quite satisfied with a lack of ambition, thinking that it could have been done better and more thoroughly.

There are signs of openness, of civilization, and then immediately, at times, in the debate within this Parliament, there are also signs of rigidity, especially from the Council, of great and strong protectionism.

This also concerns the blue card, there is resistance to some central principles, equal work, equal pay, which is a sacred and natural principle, but even on this we have found some sharp disagreements.
We believe it is essential to move beyond the principle of community preference, to overcome the idea of a two-speed Europe, which is why the principle of community preference must be upheld.
We believe that embroidery is important in the labor market, but the labor market cannot be the only regulating principle.
There are other inclusive principles of political and social civilization that must be within immigration policies.
Legal immigration means equal dignity and opportunities, or we return to selective, partial, discriminatory immigration.
We would like to avoid

For this reason as well, on behalf of the group, I support the proposal by colleague Moreno addressed to the Commission. Let us try to think about a blue card that is not only linked to the 3% of highly qualified immigrants, but that also seeks to find legal and concrete tools to open the market to immigration.
Immigration must be inclusion; if it becomes a choice, it is no longer a positive policy.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, faced with the extremely serious crisis that is affecting the automotive sector from America to our continent, Europe is confronted with a very clear dilemma: should it remain inert and watch this collapse in the demand for and demand of automobiles?

of production, the effects of which are not even calculable today, in the name of an abstract consistency for a theoretical model of market liberalism, of total respect for competition, as some voices have also been heard today, or to take responsibility to adequately address the situation.
We are firmly in favor of this second option, and we call on the Commission and the Council for decisiveness and determination.
We appreciated Commissioner Verheugen's words and hope that some colleagues do not dampen this determination too much.
This is an exceptional situation, therefore the responses must also be exceptional.

Moreover, dear colleagues, the financial crisis has revealed certain actions taken by political and economic authorities, who made decisions regarding behavior and the investment of public funds that, just a few months prior, were unthinkable.

But our intervention, and I conclude, must be selective. We need to reconcile strategy with emergency, supporting both through favorable credits and demand support, a selective orientation towards environmentally more sustainable productions.
Mr. President of the Council, unfortunately, the terrorist events that have followed since 2001, the recent incidents we have witnessed, have not been fully ascertained.
In today's India, the various conflicts present in many parts of the world make this topic, the issue of the arms trade, of particular importance for the present and the future in a broad sense.
Often, all too often, the commendable intentions expressed in statements of principle do not find concrete implementation in practice.

It escapes no one that the topic is sensitive, involving significant industrial and commercial processes, and thus the difficulty of ratifying a system of control and regulation by all States, especially the Member States, is understandable.
However, the rapid succession of events and the awareness that internal and external arms trafficking exists illegally underscore the urgency of regulating this sector in a legally effective manner.
Even the directive currently being drafted on intracommunity transfers of defense-related goods will have real meaning if the code of conduct is promptly ratified.
I regret that the incumbent Prime Minister has left, but after the things he said and thus neglecting some other aspects I had prepared, after what he said, it seems that everything is in order.
In reality, it doesn't seem to me that it is so, absolutely.
So I believe that the commitment made by the Minister this evening here, like many other commitments made by many others in different circumstances, I believe it can be achieved.
Translate in this course of the end of the French Presidency into a profound stimulus also for next week so that the code of conduct is ratified at least by all Member States.
It would be commendable if France were to do this, rather than merely declaring it here in the Chamber and then perhaps not achieving concrete results.
Mr. President, I believe that in these days we should realize more than ever that, when we speak about Tibet and the Dalai Lama, we are in fact talking mostly about ourselves.
A few days ago, at the mere announcement that the European President, that President Sarkozy dared to...
In Poland, upon meeting the Dalai Lama, we were dismissed without so much as an eight-day notice, no meetings granted.
Why is it that greater Europe allows itself to receive, speak to, accept, and listen to the Dalai Lama? What is the issue with that?
I believe it is clear that we know that the European people, if consulted as European people, would be 80% in favor of the Dalai Lama.
Yes, it is true.
It is argued that the 2020 European directive imposes costs that are too high for the economy of the European Union.
Among these is the Italian government, which has presented cost estimates that are almost double, without particularly convincing evidence.

However, such positions underestimate the future price of fossil fuels and overlook the significant benefits stemming from the rapid spread of renewable energies, such as supply security, but above all the creation of new jobs at a time of recession when thousands of workers are being expelled from production processes.
Increased energy efficiency and the widespread use of renewable energy sources are the recipe for exiting the economic crisis.
Concentrating a large portion of public funds to save banks means proposing the same economic model, entirely based on finance, that created the crisis we are trying to combat.
The economic situation cannot be tackled without strategic changes.
The EU directive aims at innovation and, above all, seeks to address in a timely manner the disruptions caused by the climate change that is already underway.
A problem that will increasingly weigh on the lives of European citizens and the economies of member states.
That's why public investments should not once again support traditional sectors, but should focus on activities that bring innovation in the energy and environmental fields.
Key factors for the growth of the energy and renewable sector are the development of distribution networks and priority access to these networks.
Between the 1960s and 1980s, the enormous expenses for network infrastructure and large centralized systems were supported by significant public investments.
This aspect must also hold true to ensure the future of the energy system based on renewables.
Therefore, it is necessary to manage renewable energy generation plants with new technologies. This is where investments, research, and the development of technologies are required.
The urgency remains to adopt this package at first reading during the December plenary session, as European citizens expect.
We cannot allow the short-sightedness of certain states and economic interests to block this process.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, for the sake of future remembrance, if the future will have a memory, we are witnessing a genetic transformation of that Parliament, of that European Union, Mr. President, which is undergoing a new era.
which in 1985 she came to know well and contributed at that time to bringing to life the European homeland against the disastrous illusion of Europe, the old Europe of homelands.
Today, we are moving in that direction every day.
Even yesterday and the day before at the Council, the Europe from the Atlantic to the Urals was evoked once again, an old nationalist memory rather than a European one.
The Europe of Cadenao Callejery, but also of Winston Churchill, whose names adorn our Parliament.
Today, we are talking about partnerships to everyone who instead wants to be a member, to be in Europe, and I believe we are making them feel heard.
I am handing over everyone, look at the Mediterranean, to a surely dangerous fate and certainly affecting the Europeans and democrats of those countries.

The Council's proposal, which undermines the good balance achieved at the time, I think of the excellent work done in this regard by my colleague Luigi Coccilovo, does not have our support, as it sets a retrograde target that we cannot accept.

There are many aspects of the work-life balance, of the work-life relationship, and of labor guarantees, and it is a choice that weakens the rights of workers, which are then the rights of all of us, of our children, of ordinary people.
And I would not want this speech to be mistaken as syndicalist or corporatist, because I defend the healthcare personnel.
No, that's not how it is. As a politician, I do not act on behalf of corporations or unions; I act on behalf of the citizens.
I think of them when I make choices, I think of their social rights, which for me are fundamental in Europe.

I therefore do not believe that a good Europe is one that fails to make progress while the world moves forward, but rather makes glaring errors of perspective, confusing the weakening of protections with flexibility and freedom.
And this is all the more serious at a time when Europe is experiencing its worst crisis and sees no prospects for prosperity and growth.

If we do not understand, Mr. President of the Council, representatives of the Council and the Commission, if we do not grasp that at this very moment millions of workers are at risk of losing their jobs and feel in a state of weakness and precariousness.

And they certainly do not have the voluntary contractual capacity, let alone the ability to opt out, then I must say that we do not have an understanding of what is really happening in the social and family life of Europeans.
For this reason, we will support the proposals of the rapporteur Sergas, and we hope that the whole Parliament will do the same.
I must say that the Council's unwillingness to negotiate at this stage forces us to establish, during the conciliation process, a forum for discussion and negotiation.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, we are faced with a significant compromise for Europe, even if the European Parliament had to swallow a few toads.
In essence, the text on renewables, resulting from the trilogue, contains a clear definition of the objectives and, above all, of their binding nature.
The 2014 revision clause is to be interpreted as providing greater flexibility to achieve the reduction target, which remains at 20%, and, if conditions allow, to increase it to 30% by 2020.

It is important to emphasize that the most powerful and economically advantageous flexibility tool for Member States lies in national efficiency measures in the construction, transport, industry sectors, and in the improved use of electricity.
The mandatory 10% target for biofuels should be qualified with efficiency requirements in the conversion processes, by adopting environmental and social sustainability criteria.
The use of biomass should be directed towards non-controversial areas, towards conversion technologies that are more efficient than first- and second-generation biofuels.
The agreement reached by the Council and the will of the European Parliament send a positive message: it is impossible to tackle the extremely serious economic crisis without strategic changes.
Those, like Berlusconi, who mocked the European Union's 20-20-20 directive, labeling it a Don Quixote plan, have been proven wrong.

The package that this Parliament is called upon to approve, despite the watering down due to the selfish interests of the Member States, moves towards providing innovative solutions to mitigate the impact of climate change.
If we do not act quickly, this problem will place a heavier burden on the European economy, but above all, on the lives of European citizens.
I am very grateful first and foremost to the Chair of the Agriculture Committee of the European Parliament, colleague Parrish, for his collaboration.
for promoting this question following the important hearing of experts that we conducted in the same committee.
It is undeniable that the Mediterranean diet is part of the historical and cultural heritage of our continent, as is its health-promoting principle.
The same Commission, in the White Paper on Obesity, identified it as a natural medicine absolutely suitable.
The health benefits are scientifically proven and enjoy widespread popularity abroad, starting with the United States.
And so it happens that the concept expands to the point of distorting its originality.
For this reason, recognition by UNESCO establishes a definition to protect this peculiarity, and I would like to tell colleague Parrish that
Due to the peculiarities of European culinary culture today, we discuss Mediterranean diet, but certainly not as the only peculiarity of European culinary richness.
Commissioner, you have honored your predecessor's commitment to recognize the importance of this initiative, and I thank you for that.
She emphasized that she does not have decision-making power within the UNESCO procedure, however, I believe she will be able to express an opinion.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, let us start from a concept: the Mediterranean diet, as confirmed by numerous studies, promotes the fight against obesity and cardiovascular diseases, and in general, it is highly positive for human health in multiple aspects.

But the point here is not to claim to impose the Mediterranean diet across the entire EU or to try to favor it over other dietary patterns that are better suited to different climates and regions of the Mediterranean.
It is, however, our duty to protect it, to define its content and characteristics, in order to safeguard it from imitations and external influences that could harm its image and value.
but therefore valued, like all other European cultural expressions that deserve to be defended and promoted globally.
It is a model that the world tries to imitate, so it is important to specify its peculiarities and protect it to prevent a fully European heritage from being lost in the sea of globalization.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, I extend my sincere appreciation for the work of colleague Lampedusa, of which I share a significant portion.
On the one hand, however, I am perplexed by certain aspects, perhaps due to excessive confidence in the Commission's assessments.
Firstly, I believe that the projected growth in gas demand is understated.
limiting, if that were the case, I fear a negative impact on the funding sources of projects.
Regarding infrastructure, the related projects are at various stages of development.

Rather than redefining them in the abstract, with a severe shortage for the Mediterranean area, it is appropriate to reevaluate them in terms of development times, financial structure, available supplies, and the relationship between public support and private commitment.
The colleague then recommended a diversification of sources and supply routes.
An example is the Southern Corridor, which was constructed in Europe.
On such matters, I deem a phased programmatic approach necessary.

Indeed, in the case of the Caspian Sea, if its resources become available in the first phase, only Azerbaijani gas will be accessible. Access to other countries will be recorded in the second phase, however, making the market more complex due to political, regulatory, and infrastructural reasons.

infrastructural. These issues could be addressed by the Commission's proposal for a Caspian Development Cooperation, provided it is aimed, among other things, at facilitating the development of missing infrastructure.
As a penultimate aspect? There is no doubt that solidarity mechanisms are fundamental to the Union's energy policies, also in relation to the Treaty of Lisbon.
Lisbon. It is nevertheless advisable that the feasibility of such measures prevents, in addition to possible distortion, excessively burdensome processes.

Lastly, external relations and every significant objective, along with the role of the Energy Charter, the expansion of energy commitments, particularly to transit countries, and also in the field of renewable energies.
But what is there to say?

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the crisis in the automotive sector has escalated into a crisis encompassing an entire industry, affecting related sectors' supply chains, commercial networks, and subsequently, services. This situation presents dramatic implications for employment.

I believe that even the dramatic drop in enrollments for this month, reported as a decrease of 33% in some member countries, 20% in others, etc., demonstrates that this is not a crisis of a technologically obsolete sector. It does not originate within the industry itself or within individual companies due to managerial errors.
This is a systemic crisis and as such it must be urgently and decisively addressed by the European institutions themselves.
Some remedies seem to be identified, but it is important how to implement them, with what resources, and with what innovation prospects.
Certainly, the demand must be supported as consumption is the only driver of the recovery.

But in the meantime, while this consumption-boosting response is being implemented, which is a medium-term solution, I believe we must state that immediate credit support is needed to resume production, pay for materials, and sustain employment, even in the face of a decline in alternatives and demand.
Thus the credit sector, but we said that the how is important.
I too call for a stronger role for Europe; it is important that European institutions set an example.

America is intervening, some European countries are doing so as well, and I too hope that my country moves from generic proposals to concrete initiatives. I also hope for a stronger European action in the recovery plan and beyond.

Because I believe, and our Commissioner has also stated this in some way, that the fate of the major European companies is a shared one, and the major European producers should not face competition within the European market.

common in the form of various types of state aid or incentives, but they must be met with a strong, decisive, and coordinated response from Europe, because the fate of the European automotive market is measured by its ability to face global competition together.

There is another point that was raised, as Sacconi stated, and I reiterate that support should not be aid or, worse, assistance that leaves everything as it is, but rather an incentive for competitive capacity.
future of the sector in terms of innovation, environmentally compatible productions, and also more eco-friendly and passenger-safe technologies for transport.
We are pleased with Belarus's new willingness to collaborate with the European Union and the international community.
We are very cautious with Lukashenko, but we welcome a new approach in this context.
We will not tire of emphasizing the need for a comprehensive and substantial change of course in the context of respecting human rights.

On one point, I believe the Commission could demand clearer and more straightforward action from Minsk. I am referring to the situation of the children, tens of thousands of guests for a few months in European families.

For several years, the Belarusian government has adopted absurd and at times incomprehensible attitudes, frequently canceling minors' stays at the last minute, causing distress to families and minors alike.
hosting and giving a new sound of slapping to children who, often orphans and coming from very complicated family situations, have been completely affected by it.
In this matter, we aim to bring about a change of course as soon as possible.
Yes, reading the text of this document gives the impression that its author desires not an improvement, but a deterioration in relations between the European Union and Russia.
If this is the goal of Europe, then this document is excellent; if it is not, then it is poor.
I believe it is an awful document.
How could we envision a future of new tensions with a country whose indispensability we recognize, in our own interest?
In the next 40 years, we will have to rely on traditional energy resources, of which Russia is rich. Could we do otherwise?
It is not possible.
Secondly, the manner and tone in these pages, Europe speaks in an imperial language, not the language of one who respects their interlocutor.
This contradicts our very policy of good neighborliness and would not be right, even towards a small country, let alone towards a large country that rightly claims to be respected.

It is a matter of realism above all. The European Parliament is about to approve, I fear, a document written in the spirit of the old Cold War, one that is obsolete, useless, harmful, and counterproductive, at a time when the new American president is seeking to establish a new dialogue with Moscow.
With this approach, Europe cannot aspire to any leadership, and I hope that the Commission does not accept these recommendations.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, I appreciate the rapporteur's proposal, however, this resolution refers too much not only to this point and to this note of the oral amendment proposed.

But in many other parts of the resolution, it refers to all Member States for different reasons and also refers to the same subject matter that you request to be deleted from the note for the same subjects in other parts of the resolution.

Therefore, Mr President, I believe it would be appropriate for the honourable member, and this is what I propose, to bring the resolution back and request that it be further amended, and thus referred back to committee for reconsideration.
of what has occurred within the Fiata here in Brussels.
Fiat has invented a non-existent hostage-taking of its managers by the workers, with the sole objective of decapitating the union.
There has been no seizure, neither on April 9th nor ever.
The news was deliberately leaked by Fiat in an attempt to discredit the workers defending their future against 24 layoffs.
Fiat refuses to have any meetings, any discussions, and any negotiations with union representatives.
The sole objective is to dismiss 24 workers, among whom 12 are union representatives.
I believe it would be appropriate for Parliament to discuss not only this incident, but also the anti-union and disrespectful behavior towards workers' rights exhibited by Fiat.

many large European multinationals that then, on the contrary, benefit from the rules and often also from the subsidies of nation-states and the European Union, and which, on the other hand, do not respect workers' rights.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, I thank the Czech Presidency, the Commission, the Chair of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy, Mr. Niebler, and my fellow members of the European Parliament.
I would like to thank the rapporteurs for this energy package, the shadow rapporteurs, the Commission secretariat, and all its officials for their cooperation and expertise demonstrated on this file.
We can and must all be proud of the result achieved; I am, considering the effort made when I inherited the directive on the internal gas market, with issues that were not easily resolvable.

I am pleased to have aligned my second experience as a Member of the European Parliament with the concluding phase of this package, which I consider, among the most important files of this legislative term, to be in the interest of European citizens, our voters.
The GASE Directive, which will come into force from 2011, brings significant innovations to the sector. It is important to highlight the achievement of the option as a notable result.
ITO, which ensures the opening of markets and a genuine progression towards a system that truly allows the European Union to speak with one voice on energy matters.
The ITO is the real novelty of this package and it is on this aspect that one can say the European Parliament has achieved the best result.
The new gas directive places great importance on gas authorities and the Agency.
This directive legitimizes the authorities in their role, especially in those countries where they must start their activities from scratch.

Therefore, it is of fundamental importance to have defined the role and competencies of these bodies, and to have granted them extensive powers, as it is the authorities' difficult task to oversee the common energy market.
Another element that was included during the trilogue is the exemption from common rules for so-called closed systems, namely airports, hospitals, stations, industrial sites, etc.
They are subject to a more favorable regime, which demonstrates the attention the new directive gives to the needs of the European citizen.

It is the European citizen, in my opinion, who will truly benefit from this directive, as through the use of smart meters, they will have access to all information related to their bill and will be able to evaluate the best offer on the market and choose their own supplier.

according to convenience, because while it is true that years will pass before the effects of this liberalization are seen, it is nonetheless undeniable that the entry of new operators into the market will lead to a lowering of prices and more favorable market conditions for Union citizens.
Another important element is the recognition of European gas transmission network systems, which will ensure the security of gas supply to European citizens.
All of this also involves the strengthening and creation of new infrastructure, such as regasifiers and storage facilities, which will be the driving force behind the third package.
Therefore, the opening of a competitive market is required to guarantee long-term investments and contracts by companies in the sector.
in particular in the new member states, where the creation of new infrastructure could also help to address issues of long-standing dependency.
Consumer protection for the most vulnerable was taken into account, providing the national and regional authorities with the possibility to ensure their gas supply during the most critical times.
The successful outcome of the gas directive and the entire energy package once again highlights the role of Europe and its institutions for European citizens.

On one occasion, we find ourselves in this Chamber to defend a food, cultural, and rural heritage stemming from a centuries-old tradition, an invaluable asset that the world envies us, representing a huge wealth for the economy and also for the identity of our Union.

A heritage that today risks facing serious difficulties due to the Commission's and Council's intention to abolish the ban on coupage for the production of ros wines, an intention formed under strong pressures.

and which will find its ratification without the possibility of intervention by the Parliament, the body that officially represents the millions of citizens, both producers and consumers, who will be affected by this initiative.

The Commission proposes to allow red wines to be produced simply by blending red and white wines, as do countries that do not possess our expertise and professionalism, under the mere pretext of meeting international competition.
As the proponent of this inquiry, I emphasize that lowering the quality of our productions, the result of centuries of traditions and research, of significant investments, and of passion,

Attention to detail is not the response we need, especially in a time of economic crisis like this one, where the average consumer is undoubtedly more focused on price than on the writing on the label.

To balance this decision, it would be sufficient to find a name for the new product and inform consumers about the existence of two different types of ros, the different quality of the products, and the importance of recognizing the work and efforts of professionals in the sector.
Who will pay for all this?

Does the Commission have any support programs in this regard, or will producers once again be left to pay the price after being asked to compete with low-cost competition on an unequal playing field during already extremely difficult times?
I hope that the Commission and the Council are able to make the right choice and, if necessary, completely revise this procedure.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, allow me first of all to greet the president of the DTP party, Mr. Ahmet Trk, who is here with us in the gallery of honor and who is following the debate.
Dear Ahmet, know that we stand in solidarity with you, that we support the democratic struggle your party is waging in Turkey for the recognition of the fundamental rights of the Kurdish people.
We recognize the DTP as an indispensable tool for the promotion of democracy in Turkey, and for this reason, we firmly condemn the police operations that the Turkish government is carrying out.
Prime Minister Erdogan has issued orders against you, imprisoning all three vice presidents of the DTP, along with over 300 activists and sympathizers.
The victory of the DTP in the recent local elections demonstrates that the DTP party enjoys strong democratic popular support.

The European Parliament, in its resolutions, has called on Prime Minister Erdogan to engage in direct discussions with the DTP, but his response has been more repression, more police, more authoritarianism, and more imprisonment.

Everyone knows that my parliamentary group and the Left in Europe have until now supported the process of Turkey's accession to the European Union, while also backing the reform process in that country.

However, I believe that in these last two years and especially in recent months, Erdogan has shown another face, that of a leader compromised with the worst elements of the Turkish army, who simply want to massacre the Kurds.
The reform process is practically dead, prisons are filling up with Kurds. It is Erdogan himself who is closing any perspective of Turkey's accession.
It is yours, and yours alone, is the responsibility for what is happening in Euro-Turkish relations and the growing perplexity of European public opinion towards Turkey.

I intend to send a very strong political message to Erdogan: either make the pursuit of a negotiated political solution to the Kurdish issue a priority, which clearly involves direct negotiations with the DTP, or we will be the ones to call for the suspension of accession negotiations with the European Union.

The path to Turkey's accession to the Union goes through Diyarbakir and the DTP, otherwise it will be us, those who have until now supported the accession process, who will call for a reflection period that risks being definitive.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, I would like to thank the Council for sharing the principles and, above all, if you allow me, Commissioner Barrot, with whom I had a very fruitful dialogue. This was extremely useful for the work we then presented in the House.

I would like to express my heartfelt thanks to the colleagues who worked on this report, providing me with ideas and, of course, bringing all their expertise, first and foremost to my colleague Demetrio, Baroness Ludford, and the excellent President Depr.

I would like to state that what Demetriou, Laffour, and Deprez say is precisely the most important thing, it is the challenge for the European Union, as it aims to achieve a unified European judicial culture.
Of course, engaging in a serious debate on what Depr says, the independence of justice, guarantees, and addressing the disparities among various judicial systems, are the challenges that lie ahead.
But I believe that the work we have done allows us to be optimistic.
I would like to tell Honorable Romagnoli that, I say, from our point of view, which should also be yours, there is certainly a pessimism about the Italy of reason, but we must have

It is an optimism of the will, and the work that you too, Honorable Romagnoli, have done, and the contribution you have given to the report, means that all together we can build the European Union, and the European Union is a reality also for us Italians.
Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, and dear colleagues, it seems that the thousands of deaths from asbestos thus far, the tens of thousands of deaths from asbestos,

There are many people at risk of dying in the coming years due to past exposure to asbestos. We know that the latency period can range from 15 to 20 years, and these figures are absolutely significant.

It seems that the Eternit process begun in Turin regarding what happened in Casale Monferrato is not continuing, where there is not a single family that has not experienced a bereavement within its ranks.
Asbestos should have been effectively banned by Member States through the application of the 1999 directive.

States should have protected exposed workers with all possible precautions, implementing the 2003 directive, closing facilities, remediating contaminated sites, and compensating victims and affected populations.
This did not happen everywhere.
Little or nothing has been done.
I have already spoken about the Turin trial, where Swiss and Belgian owners are defendants.
Little was known, and it is mainly industry that has shirked its responsibilities, acting within the gaps of inertia and public authorities.
Examples of inertia are what happens, for instance, in Italy, in Brioni, where asbestos has not been removed, in Porto Marghera, in Cengio, where deaths are still being counted.
Today, the industry is asking the Commission to tolerate a further derogation already granted for a limited time by the RICH Regulation in 2006 for chrysotile asbestos fibers.

It is true that low-voltage electrolysis plants have a limited application, and only in a few facilities. However, in these cases, industrialists claim that any alternative substitute is impossible, otherwise facing the closure of the plants.

A blackmail but alternatives to this process have been found in Sweden, utilizing technologies in the replacement of asbestos-free membranes for low voltage, and a similar approach has also been adopted for hydrogen production.
Why is it that in some states one exists and in others one does not?
For why, as in the long battle for the banning of PCB, there have been countless omissions and reticences, all with the tacit approval of the European Commission's Directorate-General for Enterprise.
Even in this case, a poor example has been set.
The 1999 directive on the prohibition of asbestos required that the review of such authorization be preceded by an opinion from the Scientific Committee on Toxicology, which was never provided.
Is this how the Commission respects the directives?
To say nothing of the union, which claims it was not even consulted.
The European Parliament makes its own effort to resort to fulfillment by others.

This resolution calls on the Commission to fill, by 2009, a legislative gap regarding the banning of second-hand asbestos-containing products, roof tiles, aircraft parts, and any other items that should be definitively disposed of.
They set precise dates, once again, for a strategy to ban all types of asbestos by 2015, but these were already objectives written in 1999.
Ten years have passed and people have continued to die.
The GUE had claimed, among the first initiatives of this legislative term, the establishment of a community compensation fund for victims, and ad hoc funds for decontamination.
The request was specific to the Commission, which today, however, yields to the will of multinational corporations.
It is necessary, instead, to move on to concrete actions and commitments.
Only when these start from the very requests of this resolution, only then can we be understanding.
Today, this will is not evident, therefore we vote against the granting of the derogation.
Mr. President, I wanted to convey to President Buzek the pride that fills me at this moment in belonging to an important institution such as the European Parliament, which you preside over.

I believe that the sacrifices made by her over the past twenty years in her country, and which today are represented by those twelve countries previously mentioned in this Assembly, give strength to Europe.
However, I also wish to convey my concern after listening to your program, within your speech, which should and I hope will serve to strengthen this Parliament.
I hope that what has been announced to us will come to pass.

I hope that the next President of the European Commission, certainly President Barroso, will want to listen to you for the strong words you have spoken to ensure that this Parliament provides answers to more than

The 550 million citizens who voted for us in this Europe, who wanted and want and demand from this Parliament, from all of us, the answers that Europe has certainly tried to provide but has not fully succeeded in giving.
In this endeavor, I express and set in motion my hopes, and I am certain that with you we will achieve the certainties that you yourself have hosted within us.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, honorable colleagues, it is not my intention, nor that of my group, which has supported and requested this debate, to transfer to the European level attributions of Italian internal politics.

The issue of freedom of information concerns all of us and the European Union, which can and must regulate the matter at the community level in order to counter political and economic pressures and to guarantee genuine pluralism in information.

The Italian anomaly, where the prime minister also owns some of the most important private networks, lies precisely in the existence of a dangerous entanglement between media, political, and economic powers.

It is precisely for this reason that we are calling for European regulatory intervention, an intervention that, far from being an act of anti-Italian sentiment, aims to protect media pluralism by preventing concentrations of ownership and conflicts of interest.

For this reason, today we call on the Commission to act as soon as possible, as this Parliament has also requested in the past, to equip the European Union with common rules to protect the freedom of information for all European citizens.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, I am aware that on September 30th of last year, the Commission presented a study on media pluralism indices in the Member States.
But in 2008, a report was adopted, drafted by Marianne Micko, which called on the European Commission and the Member States to protect, I quote verbatim, the multiplicity of resources.
of opinions in the media, to defend the pluralism of information, to ensure that all European Union citizens have equal access to free and diverse media.

Even earlier, in 2004, a report by rapporteur Bogert Kvack on the risks of violations of freedom of expression and information in the European Union was voted on in Parliament, calling on the Commission to present a communication on the guarantee of media pluralism in all Member States.
To date, the Commission has not yet provided clear responses to the Parliament's requests.

You will notice, Commissioner, that I have not mentioned my country or my Prime Minister, but as a European citizen, I ask you here what the Commission intends to do at European level to ensure that media pluralism is guaranteed in all Member States.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the discussion regarding the vote that took place yesterday in the Environment Committee has been raised several times.
I would like it to be evident that not everything can be reduced to a single extremist and ideological position.

We have heard many positions from colleagues that are very diverse, much more nuanced, much more common-sensical, and therefore, being more in line with reality, I believe they are more capable of providing real answers.
Science as a totem does not exist. When this mistake is made, identifying a problem in such an ideological way, it does not provide answers, but rather creates them.
disasters, and Europe should be a master in this and not repeat the same mistakes, even if they appear in different forms and with labels that seem superficially much more friendly.

I must recall that the same directive on emissions trading specifically stipulates that the European Union's virtuous path is to be evaluated by the Commission based on the outcomes of the conference.
At the conference, we must go with certainly strong positions, with clear ideas, but absolutely seeking to fairly divide the interests.

We must also support efforts across all industrialized countries, primarily by setting equivalent emission reduction targets. However, we must not forget, as our colleague Grossette aptly reminded us, the core subject of our discussion.

But among developing countries, we cannot fail to make distinctions; there are truly developing countries, and then there are those with now-emerging economies  I am referring to India, China, and Brazil.
These are countries that cannot help but assume their own commitments as well.
I, instead, strongly request that, if balance is not achieved in Copenhagen, the European Union continues to ensure the allocation of free allowances to sectors at risk under Directive 2003/EC.

These are fundamental points. We want the Kyoto Protocol itself to retain its environmental significance, and above all, we want to prevent the creation of a financial bubble at the expense of our European businesses.
It is very important for two reasons. The first is the research topic, which concerns the fight against neurodegenerative diseases, and the second is the method of joint programming in research.
We would have obviously preferred, and this has been stated and is the subject of our inquiry, a more direct involvement of the Parliament in the pilot project.

If we must now proceed without pausing, we nonetheless request assurances that our opinion will be taken into consideration in the Council's competitiveness meeting, and that a more certain legal basis be clarified for the future, ensuring full involvement of the Parliament and fuller ownership of this research matter.

Now we must intervene with appropriate means and resources to prevent and eradicate a scourge as widespread as Alzheimer's, Parkinson's, and other diseases that are destined to increase with the aging of the population.
We call for a focus on large-scale and wide-ranging studies, aimed at both diagnosis and the identification of treatments.

Fundamental research appears to be focused on biomarkers, early diagnosis methods based on a multidisciplinary approach, the establishment of large databases, the search for curative drugs, and models of care and appropriate services.

A single appeal I feel compelled to make in this context is to not neglect either the subjectivity of patients, too often excluded in this type of disease, or the involvement of patient and relative associations.
From a methodological standpoint, we believe joint research projects to be highly significant as they address a fundamental need: the concentration of efforts and resources.
overcome those fragmentations, those duplications, and thus be able to create a critical mass sufficient to yield adequate outcomes for this type of research.

If we consider that in other areas of the world, joint public and private efforts result in investments of tens of millions of euros, we realize how much remains to be done and how much we must do, converging on projects.

on strategic lines and shared programs between States and Europe, and on common programs between public and private entities, without neglecting that international framework that connects us with major scientific realities at the international level.

What are the novelties of the Stockholm program compared to that of The Hague, in achieving a fair balance between rights and security, and in providing legal protection in both criminal and civil fields?

Safety is a right: not to be assaulted in one's workplace, to walk the streets without risking one's life, not to be subjected to violence because one is a woman, not to be exposed to acts of terrorism.
States and Europe must ensure security.
But a security measure that weakens guarantees of freedom is a measure that undermines the certainty of law and is thus a source of insecurity and barbarity.
Guantanamo.
Europe is the homeland of rights.
The Stockholm Program defines them in great detail.

Today, a fair balance between the discipline of crime suppression on the one hand and the daily life of citizens, their family, social, economic, work, and study relationships, all regulated by civil law and civil justice.
This is the Europe of the citizen.
It must be built within states and community institutions.
European society is more united, and mobility is more intense than one might think.
Mobility is now a right.
Conflicts between states are not impenetrable walls, they are networks through which society filters every day.
The first is that Stockholm provides the institutional framework for judicial cooperation, mutual recognition, and a European justice, distinct from national justice.
It is the community one, a European right, national and community, a European citizen, a European judge, the national one and the community one.

European rules are dictated by community regulations and the jurisprudence of the European courts, but also stem from the behaviors of workers, businesses, students, national magistrates, and European networks among justice professionals.
Therefore, this bottom-up process is what the Stockholm program aims to support.
The Parliament has made a great effort with this resolution, which I hope will be supported here by a broad, unanimous vote, for which we have worked intensively.
The Council is respectfully requested to take note of this.
Lisbon is not yet in force, but it is there, very much present.
Let the Council be ambitious, Madam/Sir Minister, make the most of what we have developed here and the wealth of insights that emerge from it.
In this budget control report, I must acknowledge the very important work carried out by the Commission, the excellent work of the rapporteur, and I must also mention the political unity.

This is because from the very beginning we have wanted to send a very clear message: we intend to work with great rigor to ensure transparency, correctness, and legality in the management of public funds and, consequently, in the verification of budgets.
Very significant steps have been taken with the Council, which initially did not want to respond.
I personally acknowledge this to the Swedish Presidency, which has always sought to demonstrate its commitment to transparency and fairness.
So we expect, from this perspective, further progress, because obviously it is absolutely unacceptable, especially with the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon.
I do not want Lisbon to lack information and news precisely to verify budgets and public funds, in the interest not only of the European Union but also of all European citizens.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, we were in Ramallah when the news arrived that Europe had adopted a new decision on the peace process in the Middle East.
We have witnessed the smile of hope on the faces of the Palestinian representatives.

These were intense days of emotions and sufferings, etched onto the faces of children clinging to the window grates of their homes, on a street in Hebron, the ghost street that no Palestinian can cross.

The suffering of an 85-year-old woman evicted from her home, forced to sleep in the cold in a tent pitched in the garden of what had been her house, the suffering etched on the faces of those Palestinians who, with European funding, had built a farm later destroyed by Israeli soldiers.
Israel has the right to be an independent state, but Palestinians also have the right to have a homeland, a state, a passport.
The decision by the Council of Europe represents a significant step forward, but action must be taken immediately.
The conflict between Israel and Palestine is the tip of the iceberg of a larger conflict.
On the final day, the Israeli authorities prevented us, the European Parliament delegation, from visiting the Gaza Strip.
I believe that on this matter, the High Representative, Baroness Ashton, should intervene to voice the protest of democratic Europe.

I would like to thank President De Rossa, who led the delegation, and all the other members, because during our days in Palestine, the vulnerable people of Palestine were able to see and hear the face and the words of a Europe that defends rights and wants and must do more.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the European Union is committed to the fight against terrorism in all its dimensions.

When discussing the fight against terrorist offenses, it is essential to ensure that fundamental rights are fully respected and that the measures adopted to combat terrorism are appropriate and effective.

The rights of the defense and fundamental procedural guarantees must therefore be fully respected by the Union's institutions, even when they draw up lists of persons and entities, in this case linked to someone.

Al-Qaeda, subject to restrictive measures, and it is equally essential that these measures are subject to adequate democratic and parliamentary scrutiny, as rightly prescribed by the Treaty of Lisbon.

It is therefore evident that, as also stated by the Legal Service of the Parliament, any measure of this kind must follow the co-decision procedure, allowing representatives of European citizens to fully exercise their legislative and oversight role.
Mr. President, I would like to avoid continuing to list the reasons for our dissent with the Iranian government.
I would like to emphasize, since it was not mentioned here, one of the most serious facts regarding the violation of civil rights: that directed towards young people.
Having signed the United Nations Treaty on the Rights of the Child, the Iranian government continues to impose capital punishment on minors.
I would like, after this debate, for Baroness Ashton to undertake to outline a common line for all of Europe and the entire European Parliament.
European attention on the events in Iran and, on the other hand, that the interparliamentary commission with the Iranian government acknowledges that the course of action needs to be changed.

I participated with friends Scuria and Tatarella in the protest we had organized against the Commission, which, nevertheless, through an official statement, declared its intention to go to Iran. We had instead categorically requested that there be an opportunity to meet with the opposition and engage in dialogue with them.

I would like the Commission, from this moment onwards, to turn over a new leaf and establish relations of aid, support, and dialogue with the representatives of the opposition in exile, not least Ms. Miriam Rajavi, who represents this reality.
The European Community should be doing this instead of imposing sanctions.

I am intervening to highlight the severity of the deindustrialization situations facing several Sicilian industrial hubs, in particular the automotive sector in Terni Mareese, Fiat Group, and the petrochemical sector in Gela, Eni Group.
The terms of trade are harmed by competition stemming from the low-wage system within certain EU countries, and they are frozen by Asian competition.
In light of the severe deindustrialization processes unfolding across vast regions of the Union, I believe it is high time to reconsider the policy of non-intervention.
intervention so far adopted by the European Commission and start implementing a package of measures to support relevant and strategic European industries.
This exhortation is primarily addressed to the European Commission and Commissioner for Industry Tajani.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the issue of good fiscal governance, while always having been of great importance, has gained even greater relevance and urgency in the aftermath of the major economic and financial crisis of two years ago.
International summits, the G20, and European leaders have discussed and continue to debate these issues, especially when addressing the fight against tax evasion and tax havens.
All this is important, it is a sign of commitment and determination, but one must not delude oneself that an announcement is enough.
A serious and consistent policy is needed.
Many problems remain.
Is it really still too easy to buy or set up a shell company to evade taxes?
A simple browse on the internet reveals thousands of websites offering companies for sale, even in European Union countries.
Often, it is sufficient to send an email with an attached scanned copy of the passport to be able to open a company.
The practice of creating fictitious legal entities to evade taxation must be put to an end.
This report that I am presenting is based on the European Commission's communication on good fiscal governance of April 28, 2009.
The report is aimed at putting forward concrete proposals and calls for a strong commitment from the European Commission and the Council to implement these proposals.
The European Union must prioritize the fight against tax havens, tax evasion, and illicit capital flight.
From here stems the principle of good governance, based on transparency, information exchange, cross-border cooperation, and fair tax competition.
The point is that there is a growing need for fiscal cooperation and collaboration within the European Union.
The overall goal we should aim for is to achieve automatic information exchange on a global and multilateral scale, starting, of course, from the European Union.
The banking secrecy must be completely abolished in the countries of the European Union, and the regime of exemption from these agreements must be ended without further delay.
temporary measure authorizing the application of a withholding tax at source, often evaded or underestimated, in lieu of information exchange.
I do not intend to elaborate on the specific proposals contained in the report.
I emphasize that we still need, in particular, to expand the scope of the 2003 Savings Directive, combat VAT fraud, and establish a public register of the Union.
The Commission has also proposed establishing a monitoring system that keeps track of individuals or businesses that have set up companies or opened accounts in tax havens.

It is also necessary for the European Union to speak with one voice internationally, to advocate for the improvement of OECD regulations to achieve automatic information exchange, rather than exchange upon request.

Commissioner Kovac, having also heard the other reports, we require a strong commitment from the Commission. At this time, we need these priorities to be emphasized to the new Commission during the handover process.
We will hold the Council and the European Commission to account for the work.
I would like to thank my colleagues and especially the shadow rapporteurs for their contribution to this work, which I hope will be approved by the Parliament.

Mr. President, I must admit that when we speak of counter-terrorism, discussing only intelligence and technology, I always have the impression that we insist on examining the issue inadequately, as if we wanted to cure a disease by focusing solely on its symptoms and not its causes.
Is it not high time to tackle the problem of terrorism by addressing its core, rather than merely focusing on its external phenomenology?

Addressing the core of the issue means, for instance, acknowledging that terrorism is also a direct manifestation of the inability or unwillingness of ethnic groups to integrate into the European cultural fabric.
I wonder, and I ask this Parliament, do we want to discuss terrorism?
Let this Parliament then have the courage to politically address a debate on the degree of integration of Muslims in Europe and their willingness to share Western values, rights, and freedoms.
In this regard, I have submitted a question to the Commission on the full-face veil to encourage this Assembly to openly confront the issue.
It seems to me that there is no intention to address the topic.
I wonder, and I ask you, honorable colleagues, from all political groups, if not on these issues, on what others should the political voice of the peoples of Europe be expressed?

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, concluding the negotiation with Croatia by 2010 is an achievable goal, and the report fulfills the task of highlighting in a balanced manner the progress made and the steps still to be taken.
Now it is the justice sector that still requires significant reforms.
In fact, it is not enough to complete the necessary systemic reforms and adopt new laws, and to cooperate as necessary with the International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia.
I insist on the need to create a genuine legal culture and mindset in line with European standards.

The independence of the judiciary becomes crucial, a central issue, along with the training, recruitment, and careers of judges. This includes the absence of various types of influence exerted by the government on judges.
I appeal to the Commission to consider the necessity of decisive measures in this regard during the final phase of the negotiation.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, Croatia's accession to the European Union strengthened the consolidation of a European identity capable of expressing the common values of the new Europe without eclipsing, but rather integrating, the specific characteristics of its many facets.

The Republic of Croatia has made commendable efforts in aligning itself with the required parameters, particularly in combating organized crime through new anti-mafia measures. However, it needs to make further efforts, especially in the judicial sector, before the 2010 negotiations can be concluded.

Further steps can be taken by the institutions of the Republic of Croatia to align with the provisions of the first protocol of the European Convention on Human Rights, signed in Paris in 1952, by considering the restitution of nationalized property to its legitimate owners.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, once again, there has recently been an environmental disaster in Italy, affecting the Lambro River and the Po River.
Recently, the Court of Justice in Luxembourg has convicted Italy for the danger posed to public health, due to illegal waste disposal and the failure to control waste collection in Campania.
And news of recent days of the increase in leukemias in Taranto through the Ilva steel plant, as well as asbestos disposal in schools in Crotone, and dioxin in Campania.
It is an ongoing environmental disaster.

I strongly inquire of the Commission what actions it intends to take to bring the Italian government into line with the standards of European Union directives, especially in light of the Court of Justice's ruling the other day.
The city of Naples has been exposed to public ridicule for many weeks and months around the world.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, this debate is not ritualistic but aims to be very practical and to ask clear and precise questions about how many resources are needed and where they will be obtained. I hope, and Parliament hopes, that the responses today and in the upcoming Councils on March 12th and 25th will be equally clear and precise.

We firmly wish to tell the Commission and the Council that the European Union, which has raised the flag of the fight against atmospheric emissions and the climate challenge before the world, today has a duty of consistency if it does not want to lose credibility.
You must do everything possible to ensure these goals are achieved.

We must be very well aware that talking about a low-emission economy means a kind of Copernican revolution for the productive system, it means changing many things, having clear priorities, political will, but above all adequate resources and tools.
We also know that this Copernican revolution is essential if our productive system, European industry, is to remain competitive.
I mean that in many countries, in many research centers, in many universities, the intelligences are ready, the capabilities exist, the will is there; now it is a matter of igniting this engine.
Everyone must do it, said the Commissioner, said the Council, it must be done by the Member States, entrepreneurs, and private entities.
But I believe that the indispensable task of bringing together this complex partnership falls to the European Union.
To constructively address the employment issue, the guiding principles for community actions are threefold: react, evolve, and protect.

React, that is, move away from the celebratory tones of Europropaganda to tackle in a concrete way the problems afflicting EU citizens, ensuring a direct link between the world of education and the needs of the market and the territory, and improving young people's perception of manual professions.

To evolve, that is, to make the EU 2020 strategy a positive synthesis between the demands of businesses and those of workers, in favor of a labor market where the flexibility of contractual forms responds to the instability of market demand.

To protect, that is, to provide jobs for those who have lost them, first and foremost among our own citizens. Member States must therefore assess immigration policies based on the actual need for immigration, and with 23 million unemployed, the possibility of blocking non-EU immigration for several years should be considered.
I see no other way to protect our work and our social system.
What is needed is practicality, courage, and decentralization.

Mr. President, this is an oral amendment to point 13, where it invites the Commission to assess, in the current situation, the possibility of providing verified humanitarian aid in light of the situation.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, I would like to emphasize once again the importance of the written declaration on corruption that I proposed together with four other members of parliament and which was approved by a majority of the European Parliament, thereby committing the Council and the Commission to truly effective legislation on corruption.

I have returned, on behalf of the budget control committee, from a visit to Greece, and certainly one of the reasons for Greece's structural crisis also depends on the waste of public funds, a situation that also occurs in Italy.

Corroded by corruption, as has emerged in recent days, corruption that primarily flows through the illegal management of public funds, the relationship between a segment of politicians and a portion of entrepreneurs, and the organized white-collar criminality.

It is important that the European Parliament exert all its pressure on the Commission and the Member States, that Member States that do not comply are sanctioned, and that European institutions responsible for controlling corruption and combating organized crime are strengthened.
In the male-female relationship, we are well aware that this difference is even more pronounced in the realm of independent activities.
Indeed, all too often, women have been compelled to sacrifice their professional ambitions in the name of assuming the role and the workload that stems from absolute dedication to the family.

To solve this problem, I believe it is necessary to implement measures such as those contained in the directive we are discussing, while keeping a steadfast eye on the polar star of the family. Only this can give meaning and hope of success to these very measures.

Freeing women from the anguishing dilemma of choosing between the roles of mother, wife, and entrepreneur means lightening the burden of family responsibilities and addressing the concrete issues through specific and positive measures of family support.
Placing the family at the center is crucial; otherwise, any package of measures will be an inconsistent set of interventions, ultimately proving futile.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, Mr. Commissioner, today we find ourselves discussing organ transplantation, which undoubtedly represents one of the most positive aspects of progress in the field of healthcare.
But on the other hand, it raises a whole series of issues regarding the rights of the donor and the patient, which need to be addressed on ethical, social, legal, and economic levels.
It involves initiating a virtuous process to address the severe imbalance between the need for organs and the quantity available, while still respecting the principle of free and voluntary donation.
every form of commercialization and illegal trafficking, ensuring the quality and safety of organs intended for transplantation, with measures that can combine confidentiality with traceability.

It goes without saying that, in a context of cross-border exchanges and significant differences between the transplant systems adopted in the various Member States, these objectives can only be achieved by promoting coordination and cooperation.
In this regard, I believe it would be highly important to establish a European database and adopt common quality and security standards.
We must be careful, however, not to introduce unnecessary forms of rigidity or create additional bureaucratic burdens that compromise what is currently being done correctly and effectively.
Here, it would not only be contrary to our objectives.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, I thank the rapporteur for the excellent work done on the European Union's accession to the Human Rights Convention, which has reached its first agreement in two years.

It represents a benefit for European citizens, as it will establish a new court outside the European Union to ensure that the rights of European citizens are always respected by the European Union and its Member States.

By virtue of the principle of democracy, the European Union and its Member States must always have the right to defend themselves. For this reason, I believe it is fundamental that every nation adhering to the convention should have a judge who can explain the context of each appeal.

I believe that the European Parliament has an informal body aimed at coordinating the exchange of information between the Parliament and the Parliamentary Assembly of the Council, and it is important that the Parliament is also consulted and involved in the negotiation process.
I would also add that European citizens have the right to understand the mechanisms of this accession, as they have the right to know what their rights are.

Therefore, I deem it essential for the Council of Europe and the European Union to consider developing guidelines, with a clear explanation of all the effects and implications that accession will entail.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, 170 measures in five years, figures that are too ambitious for a program lacking a true focus, especially on certain issues.
On immigration, the program, beyond the official documents, reveals an embarrassing weakness. What is the point of promising and strengthening bodies and agencies if there is no political strategy?

A truly useful strategy must be based on several key points: combating illegal immigration along the southern border, sharing information and efforts among all European Union states to counter clandestinity, a policy of agreements with third countries, and above all, recognizing that immigration, especially during times of crisis, is not a resource.
From the Parliament's Home page, we read that more than 20% of young people in Europe are unemployed.
In a continent with 25 million unemployed, the Commissioner for Home Affairs states that the issue of migration must be based on solidarity.

Instead, we need to think with concreteness and realism. Today, the priority is to provide jobs for our citizens; everything else is empty rhetoric that helps neither the integration of immigrants nor our own people.
I would like to take this opportunity to urge the Presidency to intervene in order to make long-term connections more effective.
Direct flights between Strasbourg and European capitals should be established to avoid causing further inconvenience to those who have to take three or four flights to reach Strasbourg.
I kindly request your appropriate intervention.

The financial crisis of these months and years, the new Lisbon Treaty with its new responsibilities, and the challenge we have set ourselves with Europe 2020 require the mobilization of new and substantial financial resources.
The paradox we are witnessing in this discussion as well is that, at present, both the Commission and the Council appear silent, unable to make choices and determine decisions.
However, we know that if we want to emerge from this difficult economic and social phase, if we want to tackle the major issues of the environment, development, cohesion policy, and...
If we want to improve agriculture in the coming years, we need to invest more in Europe and in Europe's role, and thus in Europe's essential role, that is, its budget.
For this reason, we must not be afraid to discuss, even in a time of financial constraints, investing more in resources.
having the strength and ability to foster a debate and a discussion that addresses the issue of more resources, as well as the themes of greater quality and flexibility in their use.
But this is the challenge that lies ahead of us.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the European Parliament is called upon, as we know, to express itself definitively on food information to consumers.
It must be stated at the outset that this was an objectively arduous, lengthy, and contentious legislative process, which could not be shortened.

The aim is indeed to harmonize Community law on food through regulations that ensure transparent consumer information, thus preventing them from making confused or potentially harmful choices, even with regard to their health.

The report by Honorable Sommer, who should be acknowledged for her effort in synthesizing multiple needs, aims therefore to remedy disputes and the various information systems in place in the countries of the Union.

It is no coincidence that national regulations to this day differ in the terminology used to describe the nature of the regulations governing sales, creating a system that varies from country to country and also fostering unfair competition to the detriment of potential consumers.
Thus, based on the proposal of the European Commission, an attempt has been made to give a new form to the existing legislation, involving food industries on one hand and consumers on the other.
Simultaneously, the regulation commits the European food industry to clarify the mandatory indications, the declaration and presentation of nutritional and nutritional values.

In a globalized market, the European Union could not exempt itself from adequately innovating food legislation to better protect the food trade and safeguard it from increasingly invasive and cutthroat international competition.

It is not new to hear about the dangers of food products that, on television, bear labels and indications that often do not meet dietary requirements, yet are still marketed as food and beneficial for human health.
Madam Commissioner, we have requested this oral question and a parliamentary resolution to make it clear to the Commission that a long-term solution is not feasible.
Within the framework of the Stockholm Programme, the development of a widespread European legal culture across the territory, our territory, is of great importance.

I would like to state immediately that this is important, but also that, in light of the communication that the Commission will have to provide us on future pilot projects, as has been mentioned, we would like to clarify a few concepts.
Firstly, that the consultations start early, the consultations of the Parliament, and that they reach the initial phase, when one begins to outline the idea.
of these future projects, as we do not want to arrive too late, when the projects are already formulated in a fairly complete manner.
And I say this because we have some fundamental observations to make.
Given that the national magistrate, the lawyer of the individual States, is today a decisive piece in the construction of Europe.
Because, by interpreting national rights in a European key, it provides the conditions to resolve conflicts and regulate the daily lives of citizens.
Thus, it founds a European sensitivity in all those who live in these territories, so that they can touch with hand and heart the rights of European citizens.
It is an advantage that the introduction of European elements into the legal systems of all Member States, and thus primarily into Community law, improves the lives of citizens.
True advantages are offered to address a range of problems that would otherwise remain unsolved.
And I would like to say with this that we would like to overturn the structure a bit.
