For example, we would not agree that these projects are in the style of Erasmus, because the number of judges and lawyers involved in Erasmus-style projects would be
very low, as it inevitably must be, due to the high costs of physical mobility in this field, and therefore not very significant in the overall context of the magistratures.
But the most important issue concerns the term familiarization of the courses that we have introduced in our document.

Judges are not schoolchildren sitting at desks being taught lessons; they are mature, highly professional individuals with limited time available for this and are not easily reassigned, but they contribute...
They must be stimulated so that this knowledge of theirs can tackle the new challenges of European law and European culture, creating predominantly virtual rather than real exchange conditions.
And starting not so much from a general approach, but from individual cases, from the specific problems that judges and lawyers encounter, which are the very problems that citizens must face.
which are new and which must stimulate the professional growth of these legal operators, within an effectively increased incentive on their part.
We must contribute to their autobiographical reflection on their experiences, on what they have learned, in order to respond to the challenges that Europe is presenting in positive terms.

As you see, Mr. President, Madam Commissioner, we aim to introduce something new into the tradition of courses that have been offered to us until now, which we find to be rather ineffective for this purpose.

We need to know how much funding is available and express doubt about the idea, as written in the communication, of a central European institution governing this process, because we are in favor of a bottom-up movement rather than centralization.
This is a new approach.
What we mean, however, is that if a European mindset is not formed among magistrates and lawyers, who thus offer their services to justice and to the citizens who demand it, we will not build Europe.
So this is not just an important document for European justice, it is an important charter for the entire development of European unity.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the proposal on the rights of bus passengers aims to improve and protect passengers, particularly those with disabilities or reduced mobility.
This is the first regulation on the rights of bus passengers and should provide guarantees for passengers, as is already the case in the rail and air sectors.
The position in the second reading aims to establish a series of rights for passengers who decide to travel by bus.

I agree with the approach of rapporteur Cancin, whom I thank for the excellent work done, and believe that the scope of the regulation should be amended to exclude regional services when they are integrated with urban and suburban services.
It would be fair and necessary to ensure the rights of passengers in the event of accidents, cancellations, or delays at departure, as had already been decided by the Parliament in its first reading.

Equally important is the issue of providing information on passenger rights. In fact, it would be useful to give passengers information about connections with other modes of transport, which will also ensure dialogue between passenger transport services by bus and by rail.

Regarding individuals with disabilities, it is necessary to ensure maximum protection for people with reduced mobility. I would propose using the term '24 hours' instead of '48 hours' to request assistance, as well as stronger guarantees for reimbursement and replacement of the tools that ensure the mobility of people with disabilities in case of loss or damage.
Furthermore, taking into account the needs of passengers with reduced mobility, any architectural barriers should be removed and existing infrastructure improved to make it accessible.
This regulation aims to enhance the competitiveness of the bus sector, promote intermodality, but above all, to improve passenger travel conditions.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, I would like to thank rapporteur Sterckx for his excellent work on this report, which addresses how to extend free movement in the maritime sector for navigation within the European Union.
I share with the rapporteur the aim of this directive, which is to exempt all maritime freight transport within the European Union from unnecessary administrative formalities.

In fact, to achieve a European maritime space without borders, it is not only important that the various competent authorities cooperate satisfactorily, but also that the various simplification systems be applied simultaneously.
This is necessary to ensure the smooth functioning of the entire European maritime space without borders, to make sea freight transport more attractive and to optimize its use.

Harmonizing administrative procedures among Member States will enable smoother navigation between the various ports of the European Union and boost maritime freight traffic, which currently accounts for less than 10% of the total.
To date, navigation continues to be hindered by the administrative formalities imposed upon it.
Electronic systems should therefore be brought into operation as quickly as possible, as this would allow for a faster data exchange system.

Furthermore, interoperability is crucial for achieving genuine administrative simplification. Indeed, the transmission of information via email is not fully efficient and proves useless if information systems are not technically interoperable.
As for language, I believe that the use of a common language would undoubtedly benefit European maritime navigation.
In this way, communication would be more efficient, causing less confusion and reducing administrative delays.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, first of all, I would like to congratulate our rapporteur, Mr. Kramer, in particular, because we all know that we have truly achieved a result that sometimes seemed unlikely.
I would like to remind you that this file was indeed considered a file at risk of entering a conciliation procedure.
So, it is evident to all from the Commissioner's words that we are faced with a task that has been complex and has required a great deal of time.
One need only consider a directive from 1996, and this work leads us to the fifth and most significant amendment to the directive on industrial emissions.
Just these few data, I believe, tell us alone of all the shortcomings and also the defects of this regulation.
A directive that is difficult to implement; I would like to recall that nine Member States are subject to infringement procedures, and with a scope so broad as to sometimes be inappropriate.

Here, we must not hide the fact that this has entailed considerable efforts, requiring sacrifices from all the institutions involved, all political groups, and all national delegations, and has often placed us before truly difficult choices.

However, I am here this evening to state with conviction that, in my opinion, we have achieved the best possible results in safeguarding competition, protecting the environment, and promoting European industrial and employment policy.
We truly have, on the one hand, a directive that imposes common obligations on all Member States, but on the other hand, a directive that also allows for the flexibility that is necessary.

I truly hope that the outcomes of this recast will be, in the short term, the reduction of administrative burdens and, in the medium term, the improvement of environmental performance and the strengthening of the European industry.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, I would like to highlight the situation in which the Church finds itself facing a reality that, for too long, has not been given the importance it deserves.
that is, the instability in Central Asia, which unfortunately is growing, while the hopes for democracy and economic progress, at least in some of these countries, prove to be particularly fragile.

Kyrgyzstan has endured intense clashes over the past month, which will leave, at least in the immediate future, a legacy of interethnic hatred that will make stabilizing the country even more challenging than it was previously.

The task of the international community and the European Union in particular, as has already been stated, is to assist the Kishida as much as possible under three aspects through immediate aid for the victims.

Secondly, through the provision of long-term financial assistance, the European Union, as part of its strategy for growth and development, must be able to effectively contribute to supporting growth requirements and needs.

strategy for Central Asia and the instruments implemented in this context, through political support to back the process of returning to constitutional legality and the establishment of a genuine rule of law.
The constitutional referendum, held in crisis since June 28th under obviously very difficult conditions, can be considered a first step on the path towards a return to constitutional order.

The electoral process on June 28, among other things, received a positive assessment from the OSCE's observation commission, which obviously took into account the special conditions under which the referendum was held.
The new constitutional order of the Church will be more oriented towards a parliamentary system than a presidential one.
This may allow for a better consideration of the country's varied ethnic composition and the need to obtain the consent of the various components of such a fragmented and diverse nation.
The European Union and Kyrgyzstan are bound by a Partnership and Cooperation Agreement, which provides for regular meetings of a Parliamentary Cooperation Commission.
It is our hope that our interparliamentary relations can resume as soon as possible with the participation of a democratically elected Parliament.
In the immediate term, as already mentioned, the cricket player needs stability and our political-economic support. Let's try not to be stingy in both respects.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the European Council, which no one voted for, today we also have a rotating presidency in the hands of a government discredited by its own citizens.

This alone is enough to understand why Europe is in the midst of a profound crisis, a Europe that has become a political paradox in the hands of a political elite with which citizens no longer identify.
The non-Belgian presidency's program discusses structural reforms, employment growth, financial stability, and competitiveness, and the chosen instrument would be the EU 2020 strategy.
The current crisis, however, should prompt Europe to adopt ingredients vastly different from those which led to failure.

A comprehensive rethinking is necessary, because the crisis is not the mirror of decline, but rather the death certificate of the European social model that europropaganda would instead prescribe as a cure.
Today, Europe is an immense structure crumbling under the weight of democracy, centralism, and obstacles to free enterprise.
To emerge from the crisis, Europe must change its vocabulary: more decentralization, less bureaucracy, more concrete actions, and greater attention to the real problems of citizens.
Everything else will only inexorably accelerate decline.

I would like to emphasize in this intervention how the progressive erosion of European farmers' incomes at the expense of growing agricultural and farming problems represents an opportunity for the future.

The profit margins of the agri-industrial supply chain are creating a concerning economic marginalization of those employed in the agricultural sector, leading to subsequent abandonment of these activities.
Thus, a change of course is imperative, which the European Commission itself acknowledges and which the report under discussion in the House this morning recognizes.
The approval by the Assembly this morning, to which I wish to express my support, is underscored by extensive reasoning and suggestions, including those of a legislative and compartmental nature.
Indeed, it is necessary to combat global speculation on raw materials and ensure supply security.

Furthermore, there must be guaranteed improved price transparency, which not only does justice to dignified farmers, but also corrects the significant existing imbalances in bargaining power and prevents abuses among the various operators.
Agriculture must reaffirm itself as a sector of economic and social stability and regain its power within the European Union's commercial context.
Mobilism and myopia, this is the diagnosis of the malaise affecting today's Europe 27.

Stagnation, because if one in four young people in Italy is unemployed and there are 16 million unemployed in the euro area, it is also because the noise of the euro propaganda in recent months has not been followed by any concretely effective action.

Myopia because Europe, in indicating the way out of the crisis, not only presented the usual recipe but completely lost sight of the most authentically territorial dimension of economic and social cohesion policy.

Only by placing territory at the heart of political action, and by respecting its unique cultural vocations, can European policies for development and employment be reignited. They can do so by harnessing the natural energies that each geographical area expresses, from districts to small and medium-sized enterprises and craftsmanship.
To solve the employment problem, we must first think small, invest in local authorities, and prioritize subsidiarity, protecting a heritage made up of linguistic and cultural diversity.
If the European Brussels needle does not guide its policy towards the territory, the shipwreck of the Europroject is a certainty.
Mr. President, in building an Europe of rights, a central place is occupied by freedom of information, the pluralism of information, and the independence of the media.

Has Commissioner [Mister/Madame] noticed that there is a country in the European Union, moreover a founding one, which by the Treaty of Rome establishing the European Union, does not have [the following - implied from context]...
It is the pluralism of information, where a Prime Minister directly or indirectly controls public and private television and the print media.
How can there be democratic electoral competition in a country where a president, the council, and a political party control the media?
What democracy can there be in a country where a law is set to be approved in the coming days that does not allow journalists to publish judicial news stories?
Watergate this, watchdog press that, lapdog of the regime, what kind of democratic country is it where they want to bring the internet under control?
What kind of democratic country is it where those who stand in the way of the dominant ideology are marginalized and the free expression of thoughts and dissent are not guaranteed?

We are not describing Sudan under Bocassa, Romania under Ceausescu, or Italy under Berlusconi, where, unfortunately, this occurs, partly because the European Commission lacks the courage to assert an independent and free stance vis--vis the Member States.
The completion of the internal market for postal services by the end of this year is an important step, but it would be a leap forward for growth.

It is appropriate that the Commission carry out an impact assessment, as some colleagues who spoke before me have recalled regarding the opening of the postal market, in order to better understand the needs of citizens.

How does the Commission intend to protect the right of European citizens living in hard-to-reach areas, such as mountainous or rural regions, to receive mail regularly, and what tools does the Commission plan to employ to ensure this?
I also believe that this directive, which already exists, should not be used as a tool to justify the issue of social dumping.
It is the member states that are responsible for implementing the directive and they have all the tools to do so.
Madam President, Madam Commissioner, colleagues, today's debate on readmission agreements cannot avoid the now thorny issue concerning the agreement between the European Union and Libya.
We know that one part of the agreement focuses on combating illegal immigration.
We are concerned because, up to now, the Commission has told us little about this, despite the Treaty of Lisbon requiring the Commission to inform the Parliament promptly.
Libya, as is well-known, has not signed the Geneva Convention on Human Rights, nor has it, to date, shown any indication of conforming its behavior to international law.

I think of the case of Eritrean immigrants detained in inhuman conditions at the Brak center in Libya, or again the closure of the UNHCR offices, but above all I think of what happened last week, when a Libyan Republic coast guard vessel opened fire on a boat carrying migrants.

A most serious justification, leading us to believe that the agreement signed between Libya and Italy, which resulted in an invasion of Libya, was an act of violence against an Italian fishing vessel from the Marina di Mazzara del Vallo, present in international waters.

it provides, among other things, for the repatriation of immigrants to Libya without provisions regarding the right to request asylum and individual case-by-case examinations of their situations, and it also includes the possibility of using firearms to stop immigrants.

Since part of the agreement is also secret in this case, I wonder if the Commission is aware of its content, and if it does not deem it necessary, in this specific case, to request clarifications on the substance of this agreement.

It is an opportunity to remind the Libyan authorities of their ability to open fire on vessels if there is suspicion that they are carrying irregular immigrants, because if that were the case, such a provision would be ineffective.

On the economic front, it is positive for Europe to strengthen trade relations with neighboring countries that are experiencing strong growth. However, the EU has always pursued, at least in words, a trade policy towards third countries that takes into account social and humanitarian aspects.
We must then firmly assert these clauses against Turkey, a country that is re-Islamizing and where the condition of women is progressively deteriorating, with more than
We have seen women killed in 2009 in cases of domestic violence, in a country where Christians live in fear of attacks by Islamic extremists.

In the report, the Parliament encourages Turkey to take a leading role in promoting fair and open trade. One thing is certain: we must be concerned about the political leadership role that Turkey is seeking to carve out in the Arab world and its...

The friendship that Turkey is cultivating with Iran and terrorist groups such as Hamas. Nevertheless, if a trade policy must be pursued, so be it, but this should never become the Trojan horse to facilitate Turkey's entry into Europe.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, Mr. Commissioner, with this measure, we aim to strengthen and rationalize the pharmacovigilance system of the European Union.
These are the ambitious and targeted objectives proposed by the McAvan reports, which respectively amend Regulation 726 and Directive 2001.
This was made possible thanks to a close and efficient coordination between the Council and the European Parliament, as well as the relevant parliamentary committees.
to reach the discussion today of a proposal aimed at enhancing the Community pharmacovigilance system and refining the substantial and decades-long work of the European Union in this field.

Simplification, transparency, and rationalization can be considered the key points of these two reports, which propose measures aimed at ensuring the best possible protection of public health based on harmonized standards across Europe.

Reference is made, in fact, to a wide range of interventions that span from a better definition of roles and responsibilities of the main national and supranational stakeholders involved, to a new and more consciously active engagement of the patient, to whom the Commission addresses itself.

The Commission recognizes a fundamental role for the system in enhancing the transparency of information relating to the safety of medicines, in simplifying communication activities, and in the registration and evaluation of reported adverse drug reactions.
The current pharmacovigilance system needs to be improved, also through closer collaboration at European, national, and regional levels.
Effective participation at all three of these levels will in fact ensure a profitable exchange of information regarding the side effects of medications.
The new pharmacovigilance system will be able to provide a high level of shared and secure information for the benefit of patients, national authorities, and healthcare professionals.
Just in these days, here in Brussels, the final works of this Parliament have taken place.

Many representatives from municipalities and regions discussed how to tackle the serious problems affecting the lives of our cities, the old and new needs that impact workers, families, and small and large productive businesses.
The economic crisis that has struck our societies has made it harder and more challenging for all of us to provide adequate responses to a new, serious social issue.
In this context, I believe that everyone has understood that the cohesion policy has been, on many occasions, the only concrete tool available to the regions to try to provide responses.
Therefore, we can say that the cohesion policy has been, in recent years, an essential lever for the process of European integration for all regions.
Now we find ourselves redefining this policy for the post-2013 period, and thus we are at a turning point.
For this reason, it is vital to avoid certain risks.
The first fundamental aspect is the need for its renationalization, which would be a significant step backward.

Then, in drawing up the financing budget, it is necessary to ensure an adequate request both for the weaker realities and, at the same time, for the ability not to penalize the most competitive and advanced regions.
Finally, it is essential to simplify procedures for those who have proven to be efficient and to strengthen the ability to sanction those who have not been.
We expect the Commission to move in this direction.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the path towards a Europe that is inclusive and supportive of women is still long and challenging.
The statistics are clear: the global crisis has hit the labor market hard, severely impacting women's employment, which further decreased by seven-tenths of a point in 2008.

Despite the provocations regarding equal opportunities and employment that periodically fill a consensus-driven Euro-propaganda, to date, no concrete measures have been adopted to ensure women genuine fulfillment as workers and as mothers.
The Europe of the future needs to radically rethink its welfare model rather than merely changing its label periodically.

Thus, the directive that aligns the institution of maternity leave in Europe is welcome, but it is inefficient to address, on the margins of this subject, the complementary and equally important issue of paternity leave in the same report.

The greater integration of women is not only a moral value but also a strategic goal for the sustainability of the much-touted European social model, which continues to fail to convince me due to its lack of results.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, honorable colleagues, honorable colleagues, honorable colleagues, honorable colleagues, honorable colleagues, honorable colleagues, honorable colleagues, honorable colleagues, honorable colleagues, honorable colleagues.

I would like to express my gratitude for the work accomplished with your usual, I must say, punctuality, and for the quality of your proposals, which received a favorable, I would say unanimous, opinion from the development committee.
Given what I will say, but especially in light of the work that my colleague Michel has done to date, I am convinced that the report can be adopted by a large majority.
But now I come to the report.
In the course of 2009, the European Commission presented a proposal to amend Regulation 1905, which establishes a financial instrument for development cooperation.
With this proposal, the Commission had requested that Parliament approve an amendment allowing non-governmental organizations to benefit from tax advantages when operating in developing countries.
proposal accepted by us.
But the cooperation and development regulation also includes the implementing rules for the European Union's development policy.
These regulations stipulate that when the Commission is to allocate funding, it must adhere to the comitology procedures.

This means that the Parliament has the power to scrutinize these funding proposals and, in the event that the Commission exceeds its powers, the Parliament can then adopt resolutions to request that the Commission change the decisions in question.

Only from 2006 to the present has Parliament considered that in at least twelve cases the Commission had exceeded its implementing powers, but in only three of these cases did the Commission actually amend or withdraw its proposed decision.
Following the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon, the Development Committee has proposed to apply the procedure for delegated acts as provided for in Article 290 of the Treaty of Lisbon.
The adoption of these procedures would mean that, at least in the strategic funding decisions that the European Commission must make, Parliament would play a more significant role.
In fact, according to the Treaty of Lisbon, in certain well-defined cases, the Parliament can delegate to the Commission the power to make strategic decisions, but what might these decisions be?
In our view, the choice of countries to which the European Union should provide development aid

This is a decision that falls to the legislator. So, in which sectors should priority then be given for funding: education, health, environmental protection, the capacity for good governance, the development of small businesses?
And how can transparency be ensured in the management of development aid?
These are the choices and matters in which the European Parliament should play a more significant role than it has in the past.
It is here that the legislator must provide precise guidelines to the executive.
And it is precisely in this direction that, I believe, the demands of European citizens ultimately lie.
I truly hope for the widest possible consensus on this report by Mr Mitchell.
The report was presented to the rapporteur.

integrated maritime policy, it is necessary to move beyond the phase of good intentions and give new impetus to a strategy that will act as a catalyst for growth and development within the European Union, addressing the significant delays accumulated in the prevention of environmental disasters, the fight against climate change, and the battle against pollution.
Just this morning, our colleague Pirillo reminded Parliament of yet another catastrophic event that occurred in recent days in the city of Paola, Calabria.

The Commission must demonstrate practicality, not only by employing governance tools but also by implementing precise legislative measures, drawing the necessary lessons from past mistakes, which were often due to an overly sectoral approach.
There is full awareness that this process is very complex, but we are in the midst of a difficult and challenging crossing, which cannot tolerate distractions and requires adequate investments.
governance mechanisms, involving both inter-institutional levels and international cooperation for regional basins, among which the Mediterranean stands out due to the complexity of its jurisdiction.
It will be fundamental, therefore, to understand the management of the Mediterranean basin as a common heritage of all the coastal states, based on the principle of

Conversely, the increasingly common practice of unilaterally declaring exclusive economic zones or similar areas in the Mediterranean Sea, in addition to being at odds with the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea, would undermine the concept of effective and shared governance.

In this regard, I recall that just a month ago this interpretation by Libya led to a genuine armed assault on a European fishing vessel, and it would be wrong to claim that this is solely an Italo-Libyan matter.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, I would like to thank Ms. Meissner for her report on integrated maritime policy. I agree with the rapporteur on the need to strengthen maritime transport and shipbuilding, as well as to protect coastal regions and promote innovation and research activities.
Today, maritime transport plays a crucial role in the commercial sector.
For this reason, cooperation between small and large ports overlooking the same sea basin should be encouraged, as it can facilitate a more fluid commercial exchange.
Furthermore, to ensure intermodality, it is necessary to invest in port and interport infrastructure, especially in ports that can be connected to European corridors.
Finally, I believe it is important not to overlook another issue, namely port security.

It is necessary to homogenize all security measures across all European ports in order to better protect maritime transport and prevent unfair competition at the expense of those ports which, in order to guarantee greater security, must incur higher costs.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, 30 years ago Morocco denied for many years that there was a war with the Sahrawi people; today, it is denying that there is disproportionate repression against the same people.
Yet in Western Sahara, there are deaths and injuries among a population that merely claims the right to live in freedom on their own land.
Morocco has effectively closed its borders to anyone who might bear witness to these events.
No information and no representatives.
A French parliamentarian and our colleague Mayer have been denied access.
Europe passively watches.
There is no sign of the Commission's communication that subordinates us to UN mediation, which continues to fail as it has for the past thirty years.
There is no position taken by Lady Ashton, who has responsibility for foreign policy.
A response is required, in the form of a parliamentary resolution.
It is necessary to react against Morocco by halting all initiatives regarding trade agreements, starting with the renewal of the fishing agreements.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, my intervention is not intended to be the usual Euroskeptic rhetorical exercise, but rather an impetus for the EU to start focusing more on content than on form, and to abandon propaganda in favor of concreteness.
With the Lisbon strategy having failed, Europe has packaged the new EU 2020 slogan, but in reality, it has not provided any innovative responses to employment issues.

The data confirms it: a 9.6% unemployment rate in Europe, with youth unemployment at 20.2%. In Italy, the third largest net contributor to the EU budget, the situation for young people is even more dramatic, with 25.9% of youth without employment.

In the Europe I envision, there is no waste of resources in promotional campaigns, but rather efficient investments to ensure that the educational offerings prepare professionals for the sectors of the internal market, where there are concrete employment opportunities.
I conclude by emphasizing the importance of investing in vocational training, a symbol of the excellence of our regions.

The world of craftsmanship offers a wealth of employment opportunities and a unique heritage of knowledge, which should be entrusted with the task of supporting the competitiveness of the European system.

Mr. President, Madam Commissioner, Madam President of the Council, the European will to set ambitious goals in the run-up to the next climate change conference is certainly a commitment to be pursued with tenacity and the awareness that the results will condition the future of our planet.
But it is precisely for this reason, dear colleagues, that we must be realistic and more cautious in our expectations.

The preparatory international negotiations leading up to the Cancun Conference, as far as we know, not only did not make significant progress towards a global agreement, but also confirmed suspicions and resistances towards the commitments made in Copenhagen.
China has already been mentioned, but I would like to cite it here as well.
China allows itself, for example, an increase in its CO2 emissions of 5 billion tons by 2020, with consequences that could be offset.
And perhaps not even that, but only an attempt at compensation through a 100% reduction in European industrial emissions by the same year, by 2020.

This data not only makes the proposal for an unconditional 30% reduction, to which we strongly oppose, toxic, but it leads many independent observers to hypothesize nonetheless a significant increase in global emissions by that date.

In this contradictory situation, it would be at the very least reckless and even demagogic to hypothesize numbers and sketch out suggestive but unrealistic scenarios, where unknown variables inevitably impact the cost implications.

The hope is that the European Union brings to Cancun a shared, realistic, and sustainable proposal, because it is always and in any case preferable to have an agreement that yields tangible and perceptible results rather than a long-term agreement.

Inevitably doomed to failure and making governments' efforts on major environmental issues increasingly incredulous in the eyes of international public opinionthat would indeed be a hardly reparable damage.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, I have one regret in this Chamber tonight as we discuss the Sahrawis only because the Moroccans have invaded the tent city outside El Aaiun. This is a regret for democracy in this Parliament.
The Parliament should have developed the will to discuss this issue on its own, an issue that has been rotting on international tables for thirty years.
This is the most significant political fact.
We were forced by acts of violence, not because we autonomously decided to have human rights guaranteed.
For what is it if not the respect for human rights, the fact that there should be a referendum for self-determination there?

It is precisely because Morocco is our friend, because Morocco is the strong pillar of our relations. We must firmly and with all consequent actions demand that there be an indispensable and no longer postponable will.

We must strive to create the conditions, Mr. President, so that the meticulous and confined mission is not solely responsible for establishing the prerequisites for a referendum that is continually being postponed.
We must strive to utilize all the resources available to the European Union to influence this event and ensure that the referendum does justice to the thirty years of suffering of a people.
Mr. President, outside of this issue, outside of this issue, I wanted to raise a matter with the Presidency.
I believe that some still have not fully understood what the role of the European Parliament is after the Treaty of Lisbon.

I am compelled to raise a fundamental issue: Commissioner Callas for Transport repeatedly refuses to meet with the Sky and Space board to discuss the SESAR project, which is of interest to all from an economic, environmental, and safety perspective.
I invite the Presidency to call Commissioner Kallas to the House and explain what program he intends to pursue in this area, which is extremely delicate and important to the European Parliament.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the report under discussion certainly contains positive elements. The general orientation is towards the simplification of procedures and the streamlining of bureaucratic processes for workers from third countries with a valid residence permit in a Member State.

However, as a point of reflection, I would like to remind you that today in Europe, tens of millions of citizens, including many young people, are unemployed due to the structural shortcomings of the European production system and as a result of a crisis that seems never-ending.

Even before considering third-country nationals residing in our countries, it is imperative that Europe focus primarily on implementing economic, political, and social measures to assist our citizens, above all, in finding or regaining employment.
If Europe can provide employment for its citizens, it will create solid social foundations to adequately manage migratory flows from outside.
The watchword must be, first and foremost, to foster Europe's growth on its own two feet and through its own resources.
And then there are the problems for our countries.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, to date, access to employment is regulated only for certain specific categories of citizens from third countries.
In fact, not everyone benefits from the general principle of equal treatment in access to employment.

In this context, the European Union must act to ensure fair treatment for both third-country nationals legally residing within Member States and beneficiaries of refugee status or those in need of international protection, as per Directive 83 of 29 April 2004.

It is necessary to prevent a growing demand, for example, for seasonal staff solely because they are paid less or because their costs are different and lower than those of a European citizen recruited for the same job.

One must avoid, for instance, the risk that many multinationals relocate their headquarters to countries like Morocco or Turkey and send their employees to work in European branches because it is cheaper.
For reasons of social justice, ensuring the same treatment of European citizens in terms of remuneration, working conditions, and social security is fundamental.
For this reason, I believe it is right that seasonal workers, posted workers, refugees, and self-employed workers are included in this directive.
Making differences will become extremely dangerous.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, human trafficking, according to estimates by international organizations and law enforcement agencies, is now the second-largest source of profit globally for organized crime, after drug trafficking.
It is estimated that approximately 30 million people are victims of organ trafficking, prostitution, and forced labor.

This means that, first and foremost, the fight against this criminal phenomenon of vast proportions is a battle for the safety of our citizens, against clandestinity, and against the crime that breeds crime.
In the face of a phenomenon of this magnitude, Europe must rightly implement drastic measures against those who exploit humans in various forms.

For this reason, in the fight against this phenomenon, cooperation between member countries and between law enforcement agencies is necessary, but above all, there must be certainty of punishment for traffickers.

They are not exploited because in their countries of origin they do not find dignified living conditions; they live in poverty and despair and are willing to do anything to leave their homeland for the promise of a better life that will not be fulfilled.

Europe, therefore, in addition to preventing crime and protecting victims of trafficking, must commit itself more diligently to ensure that these individuals can find acceptable living conditions in their own countries.
We must help them in their own countries; this must be the guiding principle of European political action, so that our efforts are directed not only towards repression but also towards prevention.
It is a bit too much.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, as Vice-President of the Development Committee, I am engaged with the problems of many countries, especially in the African region, where human rights are regularly violated, trampled upon, and sometimes even forgotten.

I returned just last Sunday from an official mission to the Democratic Republic of Congo, where, in addition to the institutional meetings of the Rite, I wanted to meet with representatives of NGOs operating in the country and visit some of the centers where they work.
I met the victims in a country where rape is conceived as a tool of war, where armed groups continue to attack women and children.
repeatedly practicing mass rapes and other systematic crimes against civil society, especially against women, the elderly, and children.
I wanted to mention the example of the Democratic Republic of the Congo because, as I said, it was a very recent experience of mine.
But the appeal I want to make is generally aimed at the need for a strong and continuous condemnation of the brutal violations of women's rights.
The international community must significantly increase funding for initiatives aimed at protecting women and addressing other forms of violence.
violence, such as female genital mutilation in particular, even if it is a severe form of violation of human rights and the physical integrity of women.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the European Heritage Label is of fundamental importance for a continent that encompasses the majority of UNESCO World Heritage Sites and which, due to its significance, deserves recognition.
Finally, it highlights those natural, archaeological, urban, and cultural sites of interest that have played a significant role in the history, culture, and integration of the European Union.
The approval of the brand is an important step in the process of European Union cohesion and is also educational and formative for cultural dialogue.

It can also be observed how this choice is a positive sign for future generations, who will increasingly share a common vision of the European heritage that historically and culturally binds them together.

I thank the rapporteur for her efforts and offer my sincere congratulations on the negotiations conducted with the Commission for the effective success of this initiative, so crucial for the future of environmental preservation.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, neurodegenerative diseases, including Alzheimer's disease, represent a health priority for the European Union.
The disease in question has severe implications, not just for the health of those affected.
But the costs that must be borne for direct and informal care are, in fact, high.
Alzheimer's disease indeed does not only affect those who are diagnosed, but it also involves all those who care for the patients.

A European response to the problem is therefore necessary, along with global coordination among Member States and a synergy of concerted actions primarily in the scientific and research fields, addressing the challenges accordingly.

enhancement of prevention, diagnosis, and improvement of available care, including innovative approaches, as well as the dissemination of information among States on the results achieved within these incremental, citizen-level disease knowledge efforts.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the situation is that Campania, in particular the city of Naples, is now universally and unfortunately known around the world at night, and the European Union has had to address the issue on multiple occasions.

Facing this now paradoxical third-world-like situation, I therefore ask the Commission what consequences Italy will face from the perspective of Community law and what economic sanctions will potentially be imposed on Italy if the waste crisis in the countryside does not find a definitive solution in the short term.

I further ask whether the Commission can provide in detail the data concerning the European funds that have so far been managed by the Campania region for the creation of an integrated waste collection and disposal system.
You see, Commissioner, usually when we speak of an emergency, we refer to dramatic, extreme situations that, nonetheless, find a solution within reasonable timeframes.
When a so-called emergency has lasted for over 15 years, clearly something is not working.
The Italian government in recent years has endeavored to do everything possible to resolve the long-standing issue of the waste collection and disposal cycle.
The blame is primarily attributable to the local authorities, from Campania, and their complete inability or lack of willingness to work towards finding a solution.

It is clear and absolutely beyond any doubt that the conditions in which Naples and Campania find themselves are due to the absence of effective management that has characterized the municipality, province, and region for many years in the handling of waste management.
If the collection of recyclable materials, the first essential element of a functioning waste management plan, is not enforced, it cannot be the fault of the central government.

If the Italian government had to send the army, it was a few weeks ago, but also on other occasions in the past, to replace hundreds of garbage collectors who suddenly and simultaneously fell ill. Clearly, this cannot be the fault of the central government.

If the emergency has hit Naples, while the situation is very different in the rest of Italy, for example in my region, Veneto, where fruit harvesting has been carried out for years without problems and with a very high cycle rate, it means that the responsibilities for the emergency lie elsewhere.

on Campanian politics and local administrators, and above all on the strong complicity with organized crime, which has always sought and obtained immense profits from the waste business through the infiltration of the Camorra into politics and local governments.
After the lies of the Berlusconi government, which took office in 2008 telling Italians that the waste problem was solved, the European Union is doing the right thing.
to block funds to Italy until an eco-friendly waste management cycle is presented, one that is based on waste recycling and composting.

It is certainly not the plan presented by President Caldoro that is once again based on uncontrolled landfills, such as those in Chiaiano, Taverna del Re, Terzigno, even within the Vesuvius National Park, nor on incinerators that produce death, tumors, or a genuine health emergency.
Public funds in the region, during this thirteen-year environmental crisis, have solidified the criminal relationships between politics, both left and right, businessmen, and the Camorra.

And in environmental matters, they are resolved through the criminalization of dissent, with the criminalization of local communities, families, and the territory, as the Italian government has done by using violence to suppress those who defend nature and the land.

An international refugee is a person who, fearing persecution due to their race, religion, nationality, social affiliation, or political opinions, finds themselves outside the country of which they are a citizen.
Cesare Battisti is not a political persecutee.

Despite the cover provided by France for years, we are talking about a multiple murderer, either the perpetrator or instigator of four homicides, who hid behind the pretext of political struggle to escape life imprisonment.
It is shameful for a large country like Brazil to deny the extradition of an unrepentant criminal, granting him political refugee status.
Italian authorities and above all the victims' families demand to see this criminal brought to justice.
In the face of President Lula's insistence on prohibiting extradition, the EU cannot leave the Italian government alone.

Europe has and must use all the diplomatic tools at its disposal to ensure that Italy obtains the extradition of Battisti, even at the cost of threatening to suspend cooperation agreements with Brasilia.
to provide concrete support to the Tunisian people and their transitional government, and to revive the Euro-Mediterranean dialogue, which has been severely neglected in recent years.
The explosion of anger among the youth and the poor of the Maghreb and Egypt stems from the inequitable distribution of wealth and the restrictions on the exercise of fundamental freedoms.

North Africa is ablaze and demands more democracy, more economy, more participation, more work, and looks with astonishment at the immobile old European continent, unable to grasp the social transformations that have taken place in that region and to develop real policies of progress and peace.
Europe should pay more attention to human rights and democracy, foster more dialogue, collaboration, and real economic interventions.
Europe must open its doors and its heart to North Africa to make the Mediterranean a sea of peace.
Enough with the rejection of immigrants and the violent collaboration of countries like Libya. More investments, more welcome, more aid, and more Euro-Mediterranean policy are needed.
History demands it of us.
The resolution adopted today by a majority on the waste emergency in Campania is a very important signal.
The Campanian emergency becomes a European emergency and is a decision in favor of the Campanian citizens.

We say no to the expansion of funds that merely consolidate corrupt politicians, unscrupulous entrepreneurs, and the Camorra. We say yes to European funds if a credible plan is presenteda credible plan.

An environmentally compatible waste management plan, no to uncontrolled dumping in national parks, no to incinerators that produce dioxin, yes instead to recycling and environmentally friendly methods.
And it is also said no to the criminalization of local communities' dissent, therefore yes to legality.

This is a significant turning point, a warning for the Berlusconi government and the regional government led by Caldoro, who until now have done nothing but talk and consolidate cliques and the Mafia bourgeoisie.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the issue of falsified medicines is one that is having an increasingly widespread impact at an international and community level, due to both the rise in the number of cases and the increasing sophistication of these falsifications.
It is to these challenges that the report by Honourable Mathias seeks to respond, the result of lengthy and arduous negotiations.
The report, to which we have expressed our support, has outlined a regulatory framework that, starting from more precise and detailed definitions, has taken into account the needs of each country.
We need to address all the actors, stages, and aspects of the pharmaceutical supply chain, including safety, traceability, and distribution chain requirements, achieving a good balance.
These are some of the aspects on which efforts should be focused in order to achieve the primary goal of establishing stricter regulations, thereby preventing the entry of new workers.
of falsified medicines, leading to a positive and more comprehensive regulatory framework capable of safeguarding the health of citizens, protecting them from the risk of serious consequences.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, Egypt, from the virtual square on Facebook to the real one, with millions of people demanding a more equitable distribution of wealth, more justice, and protesting against corruption.

From the transition of soldiers and the people, there must be a move towards true democracy: a new constitution, new elections, the abolition of the death penalty, more humane prisons, social rights, and freedoms.
It will be difficult.
Lurking are those who, in the name of an idea, believe they can use any means necessary.
We wish to believe in the wonderful Egyptian people who, however, have never experienced democracy.

We want a secular democracy, with a clear separation between religious power and political power, a democracy that integrates minorities and realizes true rights, public health, social security, and employment.
Europe should support this path, but invest resources that can truly foster Egypt's developmentno more dictatorships, no more misery, no more poverty.
Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, I believe that the issues related to the Mediterranean have, with this measure, entered a phase that is even more pressing than the actions we have taken.
I believe that the act we are establishing today is far more significant than what effectively amounts to the 2006 Community regulation.

I believe this also addresses some limitations of that regulation, which, being unilateral, has often left large sectors of the fishing industry holding the view that Europe is doing its part, but other coastal countries are not.
I believe it is strategic for us to address the topic in this dimension and with these characteristics.
The work carried out by colleague Rivellini, which has received widespread approval, I believe deserves a formal expression of gratitude in this context.
Despite this, I have a strong feeling that we will not manage to resolve this issue at first reading and will end up at second reading.
The report, particularly regarding the interpretation of Article 28 of this regulation, raises an issue. On this occasion, the Parliament sided with the Commission.

The Parliament essentially states that it is appropriate for these delegated acts to be under the purview of the Commission, and there is some resistance from the Council. Notably, today's absence is also a significant one.
But this act ensures that the idea matures within Parliament that preserving biodiversity, maintaining the fish stocks of this important sea, is also this operation the future of fishermen.
With that said, I believe that the phase we are facing should strongly reintroduce the idea of co-decision.

These delegated acts have a valid reason for being delegated and thus conferred upon the Commission today, but international agreements must firmly uphold the Parliament's role when they are concluded.
Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, in my opinion, we have two issues at hand. One concerns the method, and the other is substantive in nature in this matter.

The method we are employing is an artifice, for which we are grateful to Mr Fraga, namely the oral question, in order to discuss something that, following the Treaty of Lisbon, should instead be a right of this Parliament.
I believe that this practice must end, and we cannot resort to a strategy to accompany a co-decision process.
Co-decision making occurs when it is nurtured in the stages where it matures.
Today we are holding this debate, the treaty will be concluded, it will move forward, and we will say yes or no at the end.
Well, this method needs to be reconverted.

In substance, however, I wished only to emphasize, agreeing with many points raised by my colleagues, the measurement of the effects of fisheries agreements, so that they are not merely commercial agreements through which we go to buy cephalopods for one euro per kilogram in Mauritania.

These tools need to be able to measure both sustainability, but above all, the impact on that country's economy. They should assess the number of jobs that are transformed, understand the rate of innovation in artisanal fishing, and evaluate the utilization of these resources.
Not merely a straightforward commercial exchange, but rather a fishing agreement with all its implications.
The favorable vote expressed for the report by Honourable Rivasi is the result of an assessment of the management of the H1N1 influenza.
2001, which is 2009, aims to establish general principles of conduct that would be valid in potential future global health emergency situations.
The report, following a long and positive phase of revision, makes cooperation, independence, and transparency its main pillars.

It aspires to greater and better cooperation between the health authorities of the Member States and European institutions, so as to be able to establish a harmonized and coordinated risk management approach.
The objectives are the demonstration of the strategy of Member States regarding national influenza management plans, including vaccine stockpiles, and the publication of names of individuals.
expert institutions consulted by the European health authorities and an efficient relationship of trust with the media responsible for disseminating public health messages.
This is why we voted in favor.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, until today, the recommendations adopted by the General Commission for Fisheries in the Mediterranean have been incorporated into Community legislation on a provisional basis, through the annual regulations on fishing opportunities.
These concern conservation, management, exploitation, control, and marketing measures for fishery and aquaculture products in the Mediterranean.
The permanent nature of these recommendations, however, requires a more stable legal instrument for their incorporation into Community law.
It is therefore appropriate to receive the recommendations in question through a single legislative act, to which future recommendations may be added.
Today we have taken this action, which will enhance legal certainty while also constituting a significant step towards simplification.
At this point, the contracting parties of the CGMPM have the obligation to ensure the full implementation of the agreed measures from the established date.

A timely transposition was therefore necessary in order to make these international measures directly applicable to natural or legal persons at the Community level and to ensure legal certainty in the field.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, I believe that the adoption of Ms. Podima's report represents a significant step forward towards a more balanced, advanced, and robust economic and fiscal policy in the European arena.

It is now evident to all the urgency for Europe, through coordination among the twenty-seven countries, to equip itself with economic and financial tools capable of governing the economy and not merely enduring it.
For this reason, the proposal to tax financial transactions has received great resonance, great discussion, and significant attention.

The fact that the majority of this Parliament voted for this regulation is an important and significant development, because for the first time, inaction was not an option, and instead, a step forward was taken.
I hope that the Commission and the Council continue on this path.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, I readily accept the reports on equality between men and women and on women's poverty in Europe, and I am pleased that they are being discussed today, as we celebrate the centenary of International Women's Day.

Despite Directive 2002 on equal treatment between men and women in relation to access to employment, vocational training, promotion, and working conditions, further efforts are still required to achieve proper implementation.

It is sufficient to consider that, despite the level of female education having increased significantly in recent years and the number of female graduates now surpassing that of male graduates, women remain concentrated in traditionally female sectors that are often less remunerated. They also hold fewer positions of responsibility across all areas of society.

The lack of access to care services for dependent individuals, such as children, people with disabilities, and the elderly, as well as to adequate leave schemes and flexible work arrangements, prevents women from working.

I would like to conclude by recalling the women around the world who are fighting for their most basic rights. I would also like our Assembly to express solidarity with the Iranian feminist associations that are taking to the streets today, calling on women to protest without the hijab.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, I say to all the colleagues who have spoken that finally we are talking again, and I hope that we will soon return to taking action as well, with precise choices in economic policy and a common industrial policy.
Thanks to the Lange report, the excellent work done by the colleague, and President Tajani's communication.

This choice signifies several important things. Firstly, the relaunch and recovery of the European economy and the stability of employment lie also, and perhaps above all, in the recovery and in supporting everything that is currently in place.
A manufacturing sector, both in the most advanced sectors and in the traditional ones, because there is a frontier there that can still be addressed and it was not so obvious until recently.

Secondly, the recovery of industrial sectors in Europe also means that our competitiveness is not solely in the financial and tertiary sectors. Here, and it is not too late to do so, we can set ourselves the challenge of having Europe regain competitiveness compared to the rest of the world in industrial sectors.

The third point mentioned is that the new industrial policy focuses on factors rather than sectors, emphasizing the factors and tools that can truly foster new businesses and enhance resilience and adaptability.

I believe it is important to emphasize, as has been done, these new factors on which credit action must be taken. We call for new initiatives, in addition to those already announced by the Commissioner on the topics of credit, raw materials, and energy costs.

innovation, research, and the need to enhance Europe's capacity for technological transfer, applying the results of research and innovation within businesses, in new products, and in new production methods and organization.

We have a very peculiar fabric to valorize in our Europe, especially in some countries, that of SMEs, the quality of businesses, the quality of products, in short, the peculiarity of industry in Europe.
I believe we should rediscover, so to speak, these manufacturing traditions, these manufacturing roots in many countries, to renew and transform them.
Finally, the theme of the territory, which is very important.
European policies are successful when they intersect with and find the terrain capable of addressing them.
So, thank you to Lange, and we look forward to excellent cooperation with the Commission to achieve tangible results in a timely manner.
Many milestones have been achieved, but some battles remain to be fought.
Today's urgency concerns women from other cultures living in Europe and around the world, in contexts where it is difficult for them to claim minimum standards of dignity and humanity.

We cannot celebrate this festival without placing at the forefront the issue of women in the Muslim Arab world, otherwise we continue to ignore a problem that today concerns them, but soon will also become ours.
We cannot ignore the emergency figures that are growing year after year, even in Europe, in our cities, in the schools where our children grow up.
For some time now, there has been a rise in cases of all manner of violence that Muslim women endure within their own families.

For this reason, I have been asking for some time and I reiterate today that Europe should implement targeted policies to counter the spread of Islamic radicalism, forced marriages, honor rights, female genital mutilation, and domestic violence.
We European women, and men, must fight for those women who live in Europe, but not only, who have no voice and are oppressed by the monster of Islamic intellectualism.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, I voted in favor of the resolution on Turkey because the reform of the Constitution, which took place last September 12th, was unanimously recognized as a significant step taken by Turkey towards Europe.
Of course, many steps still need to be taken, and I express concern in this regard for the numerous arrests of journalists.

I underline that Turkey is the seventh-largest trading partner of the European Union, and the European Union is Turkey's main trading partner. Moreover, trade relations, correctly interpreted over the centuries, have fostered mutual understanding and peaceful relations between the peoples.

I therefore applaud the significant progress made in promoting links between the European Union and Turkey, especially those through the sea highways crossing the northern Adriatic and Tyrrhenian Seas.
Upon which now moves a flow exceeding 250 t RANUY in both directions, in connection with a significant rail and truck transport link from the port to inland European destinations.
it has been possible to eliminate a significant amount of heavy goods vehicle traffic on the roads, and I hope that this trend continues.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, with today's vote we have given a further impetus to the definitive solution of this problem, but we have not voted for the best possible solution.

In fact, I would like to remind you that the over 300 amendments tabled in the report were transformed into 38 compromise amendments, all adopted, which aim to better define the priority areas of the strategy, that is, the objectives of this strategy.

The Commission, with the permanent task force, must ensure the collection and dissemination of statistical data and good practices, and Member States should appoint a government official, hopefully of a high level, who serves as a point of contact for the implementation of the strategy.

But we could have been even more forceful and less hypocritical if, in the report, we had focused on the obligations and duties that the Roma community should nonetheless observe in the host countries.
This is my hope, namely that solutions are found soon that allow for better coexistence of this community in all Member States.
Lampedusa has been invaded by tens of thousands of North Africans whom the island could never, ever, accommodate.
Italy has been targeted for weeks by hundreds of clandestine boats.
If we do not react together, if the EU does not react, the migratory wave of people in flight will continue.
The illegal immigrants who have arrived in recent months must be sent home, there is no alternative.
But the Italian government, beyond some words of solidarity, has been left alone to manage this biblical exodus of unpredictable proportions. Where is Europe?
Until today, Brussels has been conspicuously absent, displaying shameful behavior that my fellow citizens can no longer tolerate.
Europe has left Italy alone to face an unprecedented emergency.

Instead, Europe not only needs to assist Italy in the repatriation of illegal immigrants, but it must also support the Italian government's efforts to prevent thousands upon thousands of people, especially from Tunisia, from continuing to depart.

All of this applies to Libyan refugees, for whom Europe must stand alongside Italy in hydration operations and logistical management, but above all, it must strive to ensure that refugees are hosted in all Member States.
The burden of welcoming those fleeing war cannot rest solely on Italy.
It's time to stop talking and take action.
The European Union, if it exists, let it make itself heard.
We cannot tolerate Italy being filled with illegal immigrants while France repulses them with shameful methods.
Illegal immigrants should be sent back to their home countries, while all member states should commit from now on to welcoming Libyan refugees.
The topic of forecasting adequate financial resources to ensure nuclear facility decommissioning processes has already been addressed by the European Commission.
European Union legislation on nuclear sector safety is highly relevant today, obviously in light of recent international events and the consequent decisions of the Union's governments in this regard.

The work of Honorable Marinescu, to whom we have expressed our support, addresses the specific cases of certain countries that, at the time of their accession, assumed particular obligations regarding the decommissioning of nuclear facilities and that received special support from the European Union precisely for this activity.
Beyond specific cases, this topic will need to establish an effective system for both verification and examination of nuclear power plants located within the territory of the Union.
Indeed, the number of reactors that are estimated to need decommissioning in the near future on Community territory appears to be high.

It will therefore be essential to establish guarantee mechanisms, especially in these cases, for the setting aside of adequate financial resources required to meet both ordinary and extraordinary needs.
I would also like to thank the rapporteur for their report.
The report takes into account the new developments in control and communication systems.
For this reason, too, a picture of significant heteroregionality emerges, especially on the part of the States, in the communication of irregularities and frauds.

The report repeatedly highlights the oddity of the low levels of fraud and irregularities reported by several countries concerning agricultural expenditures, structural funds, and pre-accession funds.
Indeed, there is a need to clarify the statistical data that has been presented.
The situation is further exacerbated by the well-known ineffectiveness of recoveries.
However, one fact appears clear and confirms a long-term trend.

The struggle for legality and transparency in the expenditure of European resources, such as the fight against tax avoidance and evasion, still cannot rely on the full cooperation of states, governments, and European institutions.

In this sense, I believe the calls for a revision of the Community legislation on procurement and the need for what I call a European public register of beneficiaries of Community funds are appropriate.
I would like to thank the speakers and also Commissioner Barnier for his great availability to Parliament.
We support an idea of an internal market that is capable of understanding and meeting social expectations and the implications that the social dimension entails.
This is not utopia, it is realism and also modernity.

It is indeed this vision that strengthens the market itself, because the purely economic element, essentially economism, the reduction of the market to economism, has shown that this does not solve either the problems of growth or those of cohesion.
In essence, it involves fully realizing, in the present, the distinctly European idea of a social market economy.
In today's texts, this is present.
There is recognition of social enterprises, cooperatives, their role, mutuals, foundations, 10% of European businesses, and a large part of our employment.
These are realities that are true and proper businesses, a demonstration of economic pluralism and business pluralism.

They work with capital but not for capital, and they aim to achieve labor, welfare, quality, and social innovation. They want to demonstrate that these values should and can be part of the internal market in Europe.

Mr. President, Beijing's justification that artist Huey Huey was arrested for economic crimes is unconvincing, as is the notion that such harsh treatment is being inflicted on a free and dissident artist.
It does not convince, as this arrest falls within the context of hundreds of arrests of opponents and the systematic repression of any dissent.

On the days when Arab uprisings explode, our thoughts turn to the image of cruel violence in Tiananmen Square against the young Chinese who, like those demanding freedom and democracy today with the Jasmine Revolution, were asking for the same.
China has opened up economically to the West, but it has not combined production with environmental respect and labor safety, and it fails to show any openness towards democracy and pluralism.

Our actions are not, as Beijing claims, interference in China's internal affairs. Rather, they are the plea of men and women, of movements, and of parties aiming to construct a world free from intolerance on every continent.
The Beijing government should look at what is happening in the world to understand that if it does not change, it will be the events of history and Chinese citizens who will change China.
Jobs lost despite the investment of several million euros in support policies.

This is the disappointing balance sheet in terms of the impact on SMEs of the triumphant Lisbon I project and the Europa 2020 photocopy strategy, on which it is even being decided to focus the resources of the next Multiannual Financial Framework 2014-2020.

I can only reiterate what thousands of European citizens and taxpayers are asking: what is the point of Europe if it cannot solve the continent's economic problems, cannot speak with one voice on foreign policy, and wastes money?
I hope that what I have said several times, as Commissioner Tajani, comes to pass.
I hope that the review of the SME code is truly able to simplify bureaucracy, ensure access to and recovery of credit, and facilitate interoperability.
With the directive on late payment, a concrete and real milestone has been achieved, but it is the result of political will rather than europropaganda.

If the costs of yet another strategy will once again only fund empty talk, I invite European institutions to make amends to the dozens of small business owners who, in my region of Veneto, took their own lives before witnessing the failure of their small enterprises.

Mr. President, as Europe turns a blind eye, the 2011 Europol report on organized crime states that with the entry of Romania and Bulgaria into Schengen, powerful Turkish, Russian, and Albanian criminal organizations will be able to expand their operations across Europe.
Again, quoting literally, "Illegal immigration from Turkey will extend to the coasts of Bulgaria, drug and human trafficking will increase, falling into the hands of Turkish-Albanian crime."

Still on human trafficking, Romania and Bulgaria's entry into Schengen could provide Bulgarian crime and new Roma communities with new opportunities to increase their already substantial trafficking towards the rest of Europe.
In essence, the increase in illegal immigration from Turkey and drug and human trafficking, results in reduced security for European citizens.
Europe wants to do a great favor to organized crime.
The Lega Nord party is and will always be opposed to this kind of reckless decision-making.
Those who vote in favor of this report tomorrow will bear the responsibility of a vote that will open an expressway for organized crime leading straight to the heart of Europe.
Thanks to the Amsterdam Treaty, environmental policy and sustainability policy have gained greater importance, and the report was welcomed.
Attention has focused on the integration of economic policy with environmental policy and on incorporating environmental issues into policies and other sectors.

Key sectors include climate change, sustainable transport, nature, biodiversity, health and the environment, as well as the use of natural resources and waste management, and the international dimension of sustainable development.
In June 2006, the European Council, in its conclusions, called on the Union and its Member States to extend national accounts to the key aspects of sustainable development.
National accounts should therefore be supplemented by an integrated economic and environmental accounting system, capable of providing fully consistent data.
I voted in favor of this regulation proposal because it creates new uses for national accounting data and environmental statistics and for other statistical sectors.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, my favorable vote on the Garriga report on the Union's upcoming financial perspectives stems from the conviction that it is precisely in times of greatest crisis that progress can be made.
It is crucial for the so-called European spirit to insist on and prevail in the indispensability of providing credible tools, starting from an adequate financial endowment for the Union.
Therefore, the request for an additional 5 percent for the next budget is a fair and necessary request, perhaps not sufficient, but indispensable to address the major issues before us.
It is necessary to tackle real issues, such as stronger cohesion among regions, increased research and innovation capabilities, and a greater ability to generate growth and provide employment.

If the conditions are adequate, none of these issues will find a sufficient response, starting with the introduction of this intermediate category in cohesion policy, which only makes sense if it does not harm the other existing categories.
This is why I voted in favor, and I hope that the Commission and the Council will follow the guidelines set out in this report.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the new Hungarian Constitution reduces the possibility of intervention by oversight bodies such as the Constitutional Court and increases the powers of the executive, thus calling into question the normal balance of powers.
Social rights are eroded, the state provides subsidies to the needy only if they agree to perform community service.
Finally, the right to self-defense is established, which allows individuals to possess weapons in their homes even without a license.
The right to abortion is prohibited, and severely discriminatory rules towards homosexuals are introduced.
All of this is contrary to Directive No. 78, which establishes a general framework for combating discrimination.

I therefore ask the Commissioner how she intends to act, considering that the fundamental rights of the new Hungarian Constitution are poorly compatible with those of the European Union and the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, we are about to vote on a highly significant strategic document that provides a solid framework for the negotiation on the financial perspectives beyond 2013.

starting with the request for coherence between objectives and instruments, between the new role that European institutions are called upon to play after Lisbon and in the face of recession, and the resources that we collectively decide to invest.
This consistency also implies a serious response to the demand for innovation emerging from public opinion, the beneficiaries of EU policies, and European social and productive forces.
We have done this for cohesion, a crucial chapter to decide what we want and what the European Union will be in the coming years.
It is said that cohesion is today a vital node of the European project, an important heritage for all to safeguard, to protect, and to renew.
Particularly critical on this front is the effort made to introduce an intermediate category of regions, especially because in several cases the recession years we have behind us have

We have smoothed out internal disparities, making efficient and adequate support for the less developed regions of Europe even more crucial, by combating waste and bringing the development policy into focus.
And yet, I believe that the challenge of intermediate categories with the safeguard clause is one we must embrace to usher in a new era of European politics.
of cohesion in Europe and also to underpin the cohesion policy with the more balanced, more sustainable development that we want to ensure for Europe in the coming years.
I too would like to express my gratitude to Mr Langen and the other colleagues with whom we have worked to develop this complex report.
I believe that what Ms. von der Leyen recalled is particularly important.
Langen, when he stated that we aim to retain the scope, the area of application of this regulation, remaining faithful to what was the mandate of the 2009 Pittsburgh G20 summit.
