The fundamental objective is to bring the majority of over-the-counter derivatives onto regulated platforms to avoid continuing to be exposed to a high degree of
When we reach the point, as has happened, of exchanging and guaranteeing $400 million without collateral, that is, without adequate reserves, we understand the risks we are taking.

Having said that, I would also like to touch upon two issues. The first issue concerns our relationship with the Council, and the second issue pertains to the coherence of the proposed reform of the financial markets, which we must pursue.

I raise the first issue concerning the Council, and I state this very clearly: the feeling is all too often that the Council represents an obstacle to acting quickly and effectively on the reform of financial markets.
I hope that the new Presidency will take up this issue, because even on this occasion we must take into account
Allowing for an extension of the timeline, which is largely due to the positions, difficulties, and disagreements that emerge during the Council meetings.
It is a problem that also concerns the procedure we wish to follow.
The second issue concerns the organicity and specificity of the measures.
There is not only the measure on OTCs, there is the measure on short selling and other measures.

I wish to draw attention to two points: the specific issue of the raw materials market, a particular market requiring specific anti-speculative measures, and the problem of local authorities' exposure to derivatives in the countries of the European Union.
I believe these are issues that Parliament must address.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the Fukushima accident continues to produce very serious consequences, with the loss of sea and radioactive water six times exceeding legal limits.
The risk of food products becoming contaminated is high.
Europe has established very strict controls, but this concerns only fresh produce.
No protective regulations have been issued for processed products, particularly canned fish.
We import 370 tons of canned tuna, with the main suppliers being Southeast Asian countries, which import fish from Japan.
This means that canned fish imported into Europe may contain Japanese fish.
It is fundamental and urgent to provide precise information about the place of origin.
Today, in fact, consumers know where the box was produced, but not the location where the fish was caught.

The Commission has recently acknowledged this and plans to address this gap through the reform of the Common Fisheries Policy, which, however, will not enter into force for at least two years, just as the Sommer report under discussion in this plenary will not take effect for three years.
We must not create panic, but consumers have the right to urgent and transparent information.
The Commission must intervene as soon as possible.
Mr. President Tusk, your speech gives us hope. We hope that the Polish Presidency will contribute to the fight against the Europe of egoists.
that it is a contribution in favor of Europe, which truly sees itself as an integrated reality with a shared destiny.
But as she rightly pointed out in her speech, a Presidency faces concrete problems that need to be addressed and resolved.
In this brief time, I wish to draw your attention to two crucial issues on the front of the economic and financial crisis.
First, let's address the reform of financial markets.

This is not a technical issue, it is a major democratic matter of our time. The timelines are too long, we need to resolve issues such as the reform of short selling and over-the-counter (OTC) transactions.
Second point, we are faced with the issue of financial transaction taxation. We need to delve into the specifics. We expect a concrete contribution on this matter from the Polish Presidency.
More than twenty years have passed since the signing of the Schengen agreements.
No one questions the benefits of free movement, but it must be acknowledged that the current arrangement is no longer adequate for present and future needs.

For this reason, Member States and the EU as a whole must commit to reviewing the functioning mechanisms of Schengen, so that the freedom of movement does not come at the expense of our citizens' legitimate security concerns.

As far as we know so far, the Commission's guidelines may also be partly acceptable, especially regarding the introduction of a mechanism that allows states to temporarily lend border controls in case of emergency.
We must see, however, how this will happen and whether the statements will be followed by actions and, above all, by tangible results.

Certainly, it will also be necessary to embark on a comprehensive reform of the European border protection system, particularly at the external frontiers, where Frontex must become an agency with genuine powers of intervention and support for national authorities as soon as possible.
We must protect our external borders if we wish to continue with this Schengen.
It is time for courageous choices in this Europe if one does not wish to merely survive.

The crisis has deeply marked the real lives of European citizens and businesses, and risks, if we do not react, irreversibly lowering social and cultural quality, well-being, the future of young people and Europeans.

Emerging from the crisis means creating remedies for the identified causes, remedies against speculation, which, if necessary, must also have their claws trimmed, by imposing strict rules on financial markets, remedies that cannot be called into question.

Remedies against recession, remedies against an imbalanced development model that has placed the individual a step below profit, remedies against resurgent nationalism that does prevent Europe from making the choices that rightfully belong to it today.

Above all, it is time to define the tools, resources, even new ones, to move forward, to ignite the engines of growth, through research, innovation, training, and support for productive investments, infrastructure, and labor, because without work, people are without dignity and rights.
This report, thanks to Pervaiz Bers and colleagues, outlines a possible strategy for a proud and role-aware Europe.
It is now up to European leaders, if there are any, to take responsibility for implementing it.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, behind the widespread prosperity of our continent lies a hidden Europe, often invisible, which we discuss in terms of numbers, statistics, and sociology, rather than as real people of flesh and blood, often women, children, or the elderly, that is, the most vulnerable population.
But Europe will not be credible to its citizens if it does not learn to be consistent, and we wish to be consistent in this Parliament, at this stage in Europe's life.

So, if we say that we want to base the Union on values, on human rights, I do not believe we can so drastically interrupt or cut a program for those who do not eat, in other words, for those who do not have the right to food, to access to food.

The fundamental points for an unresolved legal issue are the agricultural fund, the social fund, and, if it is to be social, Commissioner, that it not be at the expense of other social programs, but rather a new, ad hoc fund with appropriate resources.
We claim to want to ensure food security for Europeans, but the primary right to security is to have food, and then for that food to be healthy.
So here is our consistency and our commitment.

Let us then say that a legal solution is found that provides continuity and, with the help of non-governmental organizations and volunteers, guarantees the first fundamental human right, that of civic engagement.
Only to support this relationship and emphasize two aspects in particular: one because it inserts itself into the ongoing debate about the relation currently underway.

revision of the common fisheries policy and on the underlying option, which is the one related to the regionalization of a policy that, having been centralized in recent years, has shown all its weaknesses.
This phase of regionalization finds a particular application in the Black Sea.

I believe that the elements contained in Ms. Iotova's report describe a particular, but repeatable, situation across the rest of Europe. The situation in the Adriatic Sea, in the Mediterranean area, is no different.

in the Tyrrhenian Sea or the Aegean Sea, that is, the interactions, especially between European fishing and non-European fishing, so to speak, are often very harmful to European markets and European consumers.
The second issue I would like to briefly highlight is the call for a common coastal guard.
There is no politics without the exercise of control.

Checks today are carried out by disparate forces in Europe, I believe it is time to understand how one of the first, so to speak, European order forces, namely the coast guards, can have a common management, greater correlation, and why not, a single European corps.
With this hope, I fully support the contents of the report by colleague Iotova.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the disaster that struck the Gulf of Mexico over a year ago prompted the European Commission to reflect on legislation related to the activity of short-range oil platforms.
The European Parliament, through this report, also sought to express its position on the matter, adopting a text that requires adequate technical and financial capacities.
for industry operators and aims to establish high safety standards, thereby reinforcing the leading role of the European Union in promoting the safety of offshore activities.
The new measures in this field requested of the Commission must focus on international coordination and a realistic approach that combines all existing excellences.
in the sector at the procedural level and avoid the creation of new bodies or additional bureaucracy, which could risk diverting from the achievement of concrete final objectives.

The report, in concrete terms, in addition to holding operator companies more accountable, calls for the improvement of communication mechanisms and the sharing of information and knowledge. It also advocates for the strengthening and expansion of the role of the European Maritime Safety Agency's expertise.
It is for all these reasons that I consider the result achieved to be positive, thanks to the negotiation on this text, for which we have expressed our support.
I would like to express my gratitude to colleagues Seeber and Schillaciakis, as well as Commissioner Heidegger.

I believe that we are here today discussing and reasoning in order to truly achieve a strong European climate policy, capable of safeguarding economic development and the well-being of European citizens.
For this reason, Mr. President, international climate policies, as has been recalled thus far, have focused primarily on reducing CO2 emissions.
This proposal underscores the need for us to also tackle other anthropogenic emissions that cause the formation of tropospheric ozone, as they contribute to climate change.

Numerous things have already been mentioned that I believe we should keep firmly in mind. Today, we are capable of achieving this at absolutely reasonable costs; we have the technologies at our disposal. Moreover, despite any doubts, it is the CO2 emissions that primarily impact us.

Although it is doubtful that the other greenhouse gases present in the atmosphere are in much smaller percentages, it is certain that their potential is very high and that, therefore, we could truly achieve significant results in just a few years, in a few decades.
Two are important.

There are signals, as the Commissioner also recalled from the United States, I saw a study published in Nature by the scientific agency of the American Department of Commerce, with which I find it possible

There are many points of contact with the analysis conducted by our colleagues, and so I imagine that these too will be elements that will enable Europe to present itself in Durban with an even stronger, more concrete, and significant position.

I only finish by recalling, as has already been mentioned, that for the extraordinarily difficult and delicate moment we are living through, we were just now talking about the homeless, there is a sensitivity among European citizens of which we must take account, and therefore considering that the great...

As far as sensitivity is concerned, obviously, it should be our top priority, along with jobs. We should be able to launch a communication campaign that clearly explains to citizens what concrete actions we intend to take towards development, their well-being, and the protection of jobs.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the single market, free movement, and the Lisbon Treaty are all elements that have come into play regardless of a change in our legislative approach, both at the European and national levels.

If we are to follow up on the commitments that have arisen from these opportunities, in particular, we must truly begin a phase of simplification of the legislative system, a simplification phase that must lead to a different dialogue between Europe and individual states.

I take the opportunity to suggest a sort of clarity test on our documents when we produce a white paper or a green paper; everything must be more understandable. I go so far as to say that the real and perhaps strategic proposal for our Europe is to genuinely launch a...

The solution to this, let's say virtuous, phase of registration initiation is to assign a specific mandate to a European Commissioner who will specifically address the clarification of legislation and relations between states and Europe itself.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, representative of the Council, and Commissioner, first of all, I too would like to positively acknowledge, as other colleagues have done, the anti-corruption package that the European Commission adopted on June 6th.
Corruption is a transnational phenomenon and measures at the European level are necessary to combat it.
The vast majority of our European citizens, according to Eurobarometer estimates, believe that Europe should do more.
How can one fault them?

In many Member States, there has been a lack of political will to combat corruption; consider that there are still European countries that have not signed the United Nations Convention against Corruption.

When we consider the devastating impact of corruption on democratic processes, citizens' rights, and trust in the rule of law, it is clear that the national measures to combat it, adopted so far by the Member States, are insufficient to contain a phenomenon that is on the rise.

It is the European Union that must provide a unified and strong response, especially now, in the midst of an unprecedented economic crisis, which is impacting the lives of people, the resilience of pension and welfare systems, and the ability of institutions to ensure essential services.
Corruption causes an annual loss of 120 billion euros, equivalent to 1% of the European Union's GDP, and daily diverts resources from the Union and its member states.
could be used to provide essential services such as education, childcare, employment, transportation, and divert clean resources towards supporting individuals.

Therefore, it is necessary to show more courage and firmness, both by monitoring the implementation of anti-corruption measures and by stepping up and strengthening the measures to combat corruption at EU level.

In particular, we cannot speak of fighting corruption if we are unable to adopt, at the very least, minimum rules for the definition of the crime of corruption, of which there is no trace in the recently approved package.
The same applies to the definition of uniform parameters for measuring the extent of the phenomenon in member countries, essential for developing an effective response.
We are in favor, for example, of revitalizing the network of EU contact points against corruption, as proposed in the resolution we will vote on tomorrow.
The crisis is not of recent origin; it has been ongoing for several years.
Perhaps it is time for a critical assessment of the policies followed so far. Has everything always been done well?
We have always conducted appropriate situational analyses.
Has the right approach been chosen?
The same European Central Bank, which as Minister Rostovsky says saved Europe, did it always do the right thing when, fearing inflation, it raised interest rates?
President Barroso identifies a problem: the speed of markets and the slowness of politics, but is this the only issue?

Certainly, if we consider that we are still implementing the July 21st measures, this should at least suggest the need to better prepare and organize summits and their conclusions. However, politics will always be slower than markets.
The point, then, is to look further ahead, shifting the focus to the fight against unemployment and towards development.

This is the approach that the European Commission must adopt, as seen today in President Barroso's speech, where there was more concrete discussion on the deficit and less on growth and development indications.

The Commission should transcend its weakness, declare that the priority is fighting unemployment and creating jobs, redistributing wealth, and implementing a strategy of public investments, also changing the rules of the new European stability pact.
Mr. President, I believe that the challenge for the coming years is to ensure that Europe, as has been said, retains its position as the leading power.
a global tourist destination and at the same time capable of enhancing, in terms of both environmental protection and competitive ability, its entire territorial heritage.

It is a challenging and non-trivial task, especially in light of not only the opportunities, but also the aggressiveness of other countries in this sector, from other continents, from China to India to Brazil.
Now, in this context, as Commissioner Tajani recalled, it becomes fundamental, as also noted in the Commission's opinion that we approved in the Committee on Regional Development.
maintain a strong overall strategy for the entire European Union on tourism, while enhancing the role of regions and territories.
In this sense, it is essential to fully involve regions and local entities from the outset, respecting the principle of subsidiarity.
Furthermore, I believe that the development of integrated tourist networks and projects should be encouraged, starting with the creation of partnerships for the exchange of best practices.
It seems right, indeed, to propose the identification of an 'Europe Brand' that can define a high quality of the tourist product.
Obviously, it will be up to the Commission to better define the priorities, especially from a financial standpoint, to ensure that this European primacy is maintained in the future.

Madam President, honorable colleagues, the preparation of the common strategic framework for the funding of research and innovation represents one of the greatest opportunities that European development and economy have before them.

In fact, it is a matter of acting on the lever that can truly trigger a moment of growth and also of new qualified employment, such as that of researchers and young people who dedicate themselves precisely to the new opportunities for innovation, technology, and related professions.
One observation, above all, emerges from this work: we must increasingly emphasize in Europe a research and innovation that leads to practical application, that results in

We need to foster new businesses, ones that lead to new patents and do not remain purely in the realm of fundamental research or pure knowledgeimportant though that is. Instead, we need to trigger the real sprint towards development.

The second observation concerns the relationship with local authorities, regions, and territories, which are also an important tool for territorial programming and for the interaction between research, universities, centers of excellence, and businesses.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, European schools were established with the aim of ensuring access to education in one's mother tongue for the children of European institution staff who are called to work and live abroad in a cultural context different from that of their home country.
The first European school was established in Luxembourg in the distant year of 1953, at the initiative of a group of officials.
Over the years, given the positivity of this form of teaching, as many as 14 European schools have been established within the various Member States.

While acknowledging that the system of European schools represents a necessity rather than a luxury, it is evident that, more than 50 years after the creation of the first European school, this system may present outdated aspects and must in some way be updated and adapted to new economic and social needs.

I therefore expressed my vote in favor of the text by colleague Cavada, which aspires to greater involvement by the European Union to support and coordinate the actions of the Member States called upon to work towards developing and improving the European schools system.
It is an enterprise dedicated to investment, recognizing that investing in education is akin to investing in the future of our young Europeans.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, in recent decades, there has been an exponential increase in the number of natural disasters that have caused the deaths of tens of thousands of people in various parts of the world.
Last year, as part of the development committee, I monitored the progress of the report on the European Union's disaster response capacity.
How much more needs to be done to ensure a coordinated response from the European Union in the face of multiplying earthquakes, floods, or tsunamis?
The European Union's response to the Haiti earthquake, for example, clearly demonstrated the complexity of existing instruments and procedures.

Although the Member States and Community institutions acted promptly in terms of sending humanitarian aid, the management of the crisis raised a series of issues in terms of efficiency, coordination, and transparency.

Precisely for this reason, I have expressed a favorable vote for the text presented by my colleague Elisabetta Gardini, which aims for greater efficiency in all stages of disaster management and enhanced coordination.
between the parties involved and a simplification aimed at avoiding unnecessary overlaps and time-wasting that could hinder the provision of rapid and effective aid.
Yes, it is merely a good initiative, I believe that it will then be a matter of constructing a European policy towards tourism.
The European brand is a good intuition, but on two issues I would like to dwell: there is no sea or coastal tourism without a coastal planning policy.

I believe it is time for Europe, precisely to safeguard this important sector, to launch an initiative where the concept of the sea and the concept of the coast are not limited to a kind of urban planning that ends at the water's edge and does not comprehensively engage the sea.
I believe that an integrated policy in this direction is useful, as well as the need to build everything that lies behind the claims of rural tourism.
an excellent source of income for disadvantaged areas, for regions where there is no longer any work, where it is important to prevent further depopulation and encourage human settlement.

Well, it is not enough to make mere statements; one should suggest to Europe and individual states to intervene on the tax lever. Doing tourism in rural areas might mean paying fewer taxes. Perhaps this is how a real opportunity can be built for the tourism resource and for those who live there.
I wish to express my congratulations on the work carried out by Hon. Fidanza, which logically fits within the framework of actions supporting women.
learned and promoted at community level in the field of tourism, after the Treaty of Lisbon granted the EU new powers for the sector.
I endorse and wish to emphasize the statement regarding the importance of Europe as a unified destination for certified and high-quality tourism.
The same idea, translated into actions at the level of structures, resource allocation, funding, and coordination of actions between the various levels of government in the countries of the Union.

An approach that should be valued and rewarded given the sector in question, with its implications in terms of GDP percentages produced, employment, and new opportunities for small and medium-sized enterprises.
Businesses, by focusing on environmental protection and enhancement, are positioned to grow and thus address the major challenges of our time.
For all these reasons, I consider this report positive, an important signal in the direction of promoting a European policy for tourism.
Mr. President, for the recovery as well, three brief considerations: we need more Europe here too.
I believe it is inevitable that on certain issues there is truly an attitude where not only is more Europe desired, but it is also constructed.
More Europe means, for example, beginning to genuinely consider a common road police force, with identical rules in terms of safety protection.
More Europe means having a European policy on education, not simply delegating this to individual nations, but rather constructing, for instance, a genuine educational policy.
In relation to schools, in relation to young people, and also in relation to higher-risk groups, such as motorcyclists mentioned a moment ago, but this could also include truck drivers.
For us, more Europe means having common tools within our machines that improve safety conditions, anti-alcohol and anti-corruption measures.
drowsiness, I believe they are a timely strategy to be developed with the automotive industry and European vehicle production.
I believe that if all of this is framed within the conviction of a common policy, I truly think that perhaps conditions will improve.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, this report addresses a topic that is global food security. Global means that this issue is not just about world hunger in the poorest countries, but that the question of food supply concerns all communities, even those in the most developed nations.
Outline some key lines of coherence between European policies and this goal of global food security, because we are an institution that preaches very well but often lacks consistency in its choices.
I merely want to highlight three titles of innovative lines that I believe we should further develop.

The first challenge in food provisioning today is the risk posed by volatile prices due to speculation on food products, which needs to be contained if not prevented through regulations on derivatives, etc.
Secondly, the issue of land grabbing, which should be the subject, in my opinion, of some form of treaty or negotiation, because democracy, as well as the survival of many peoples, is at risk.
Third, the consistency between energy supply and policies.
We cannot, in order to produce new energy, prevent the production of food for the world's populations.
I voted wholeheartedly in favor of this report by Mr. Zimmer, primarily for a matter of security, as it is an idea that has not been accepted.
It is of a purely political nature, as I believe it is necessary to bring the major issue of food security back to the forefront of the entire European Union's initiative.
It is not merely a matter of helping developing countries address this issue more effectively, but the food crisis, as it is forecasted that by 2050 the demand for food will increase by over 70%.

Agricultural products are a major issue that, if not addressed promptly and decisively, will become one of the main threats, if not the most significant threat, to stability, peace, and even democracy, as has been seen.

For this reason, I believe it is indispensable that the entire European Union, together with its member states, make all necessary efforts, starting with appropriate economic investments, as indicated in the report, in this direction, to seriously address this great issue.
Greetings to the Commission, I must truly thank all the individuals who have contributed over these weeks, these months, to the production of this document that we are voting on in the Chamber today.
We worked, I must say very well, and a truly constructive debate developed.
The resolution proposal we are voting on today is the result of a truly collaborative effort and reflects the contributions of all political groups and the entire Parliament.
I believe a very strong and shared sensitivity has developed on this issue, also because we must remember that we live in an era truly characterized by an exponential increase in catastrophes.
The numbers, when we examine them in their raw form, are very eloquent. The number of disasters worldwide has quintupled, considering that in 1975
There were 78 recorded catastrophic events, whereas today we are facing nearly 400 disastrous events per year.

Mr. President, unfortunately, over the past twenty years, the victims of these disasters have numbered 90, with over 29 million individuals affected by the disasters, while economic losses amount to 211 billion euros.
It is evident that we are facing phenomena of such magnitude that they demand a stronger response, a more effective response, and a truly robust commitment from us.
We all have in our minds the images of the earthquake in Haiti, the flood in Pakistan, what happened in Japan.
Mr. President, Europe itself experiences sudden floods, fires, and, we remember, the ash cloud following the eruption of the Icelandic volcano, on its territory every year.
There is no need to belabor the point in asserting the significance of the work being done here in Parliament, guided by two principles.
fundamental principles, which are our guiding stars, the principle of solidarity, which is strengthened by the solidarity clause of the Lisbon Treaty, and the principle of subsidiarity.
We move along these lines.

Mr. President, the European Union's intervention has always been generous and effective in the past, as evidenced, I believe, by the work defended by our Commissioner Georgieva. However, today we need to take a qualitative leap.
A qualitative leap that we are ready to make to move from an ad hoc response to one where the reaction
is enhanced through the prior identification of existing resources in the Member States made available to the European Civil Protection Mechanism.
It is important to also emphasize this qualitative leap, moving from information sharing and emergency response to the role of planning and monitoring.

This is the coordination we advocate, the fundamental role of services such as GMES. I take this opportunity to also express the concern regarding the budget developments for these new technologies, which are essential.
We have emphasized the importance of communication with citizens, because this too was a significant lesson from the Japanese experience, and it can never be overstated or sufficient.
And we await the Commission's presentation of the proposal on civil protection in the form of a legislative act, which we urge them to do as soon as possible.
Oppressed ethnic minorities, Christians forced to practice their faith in secret, priests brutally murdered with no action from the authorities, anti-Western foreign policythis is today's Turkey.
My party, the Northern League, has always been opposed to Turkey's entry into Europe, as it represents a potential Trojan horse for radical Islamism in our continent.
Today more than ever, we are convinced that the EU must bring an end to accession negotiations.
The intolerable threats that Turkey has directed towards Europe must receive an immediate response.
It is unacceptable for a third country to dictate to Europe what it should do.
Cyprus is a full member state of the EU and has the undisputable right to assume the rotating presidency.
Europe must send a clear signal and demonstrate its readiness to defend Cyprus by all means necessary in the face of Turkey's political and military arrogance and bullying.
Immediately suspend the accession negotiations and be prepared to also suspend trade relations.
Mr. President, we are witnessing a decisive moment for the future of the euro and, with it, for the entire European project.
To have this awareness would mean stepping away from a short-sighted logic that subordinates everything to an ideological will for fiscal rigor.
We all want the accounts of the various States to be in order, we all want to reduce indebtedness.
However, it is clear that without an intelligent investment policy capable of revitalizing the economy, there will be no chance of growth.
The only clear outcome in this scenario is that, as always, the heaviest prices will be paid by the most vulnerable sectors of society.
For this reason, together with the group of Socialists and Democrats, we voted against this report.
Indeed, we are proceeding in a single direction, which is one of rigor without growth, a direction that has proven to be wrong so far.
I greatly appreciate the work that colleague Ferrera has done with this report.
In fact, out of the package of six legislative proposals dedicated to economic governance, only on this one did I and my group express a positive vote.

We did this because, among other things, a clause protecting social rights has been included, starting from collective bargaining, and furthermore, there is a strengthening of the Parliament's role in the adoption of delegated acts.

Thus, while not being able to change the overall balance of the six-proposal package, this report undoubtedly represents a step forward in establishing, among other things, a surveillance system that takes fundamental rights into account.

And so, in this context, while maintaining that a vision, in our opinion, based solely on a policy of austerity, does not yield positive results, this report undoubtedly constitutes a contradictory positive note.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, Finland and the Netherlands have taken their stand in the Council for a very simple reason: Bulgaria and Romania are currently unable to ensure effective border control, and there are three acts of unfair corruption involving the political class and organized crime.
It is not the populist parties and movements that think this way, but Europol, in its 2010 report on organized crime.
There is no populist propaganda, but a serious security issue.

If Bulgaria were to join the Schengen area at this time, police and security agencies predict that Bulgarian borders, especially maritime ones, would become an easy target for Turkish and Eastern European crime, and Bulgaria and Romania would become the crossroads for human and drug trafficking.

It is natural that some Member States have significant reservations about the actual capacity of Bulgaria and Romania to ensure effective border controls against organized crime and corruption, and it is therefore absolutely natural that they have opposed their accession to Schengen.
Allowing this now means paving the way for transnational crime and creating a breach in European borders, precisely where there is immense migratory pressure from Turkey.
The reasons to oppose are many, and Europe cannot ignore them.
I therefore ask to know what the intentions of the Commission and the Council are regarding this sensitive issue, which, in my opinion, has so far been addressed with
insufficiency and without taking into account the dangers that the entry of Bulgaria and Romania would entail, according to the competent bodies in matters of security and international crime.

In my view, the Commission and the Council should postpone the accession of these two countries to Schengen and only give their approval when there is reasonable certainty that the accession of Bulgaria and Romania will not have implications for the security of European citizens.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the crisis in Europe is entangling the issues of public budgets and private capital in a vicious circle with those of the productivity of our businesses, and the specter of recession is indeed present.
Given that the priority of SMEs is crucial, I call on the Commission to absolutely ensure, together with the Parliament, that the principles, our good principles, are implemented.
in practice, and that the legislative initiatives of the SBA, the Small Business Act, become concrete practice in the Member States, with a high level of effectiveness and quality.

Consider, Commissioner, what could be achieved if all Member States were to anticipate the application of the directive against late payment? What a great advantage this would be for SMEs! Thus, SME evidence is important, but we are still at the methodological level.

It is certainly right to check whether, when we legislate, we do so in the genuine interest of and in line with the needs of small and medium-sized enterprises. However, we request that there be a great deal of consistency and tenacity, so to speak in depth, in creating this framework of opportunities that you have outlined.
We appreciate what the Commission is doing as well, and we are ready to support it with the budget and the other possibilities we have.
I'll say just one word about credit.
Let's have a clear conversation with the banks, I tell you, Commissioner, because we must support small and medium-sized enterprises.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, I have cast my vote in favor of the text presented by my colleague, Honorable Wallis.
While not prejudicing the usual avenues of access to justice, I am convinced that an alternative dispute resolution (ADR) represents a rapid and cost-effective alternative to legal proceedings.
In addition to being an effective tool for small and medium-sized enterprises, ADR can also have significant online growth for resolving minor disputes.

Through joint action with the Member States, it is therefore necessary to promote the creation of a harmonized legal framework that, by strengthening citizens' trust in the internal market, can contribute to stimulating the European economy.

The report on arrangements for sectors placed on the market under the flexibility mechanism, for which we expressed our favorable vote, was inspired by a measured and realistic approach that materialized in the report.

on the one hand, by avoiding the establishment of unrealistic and unattainable requirements, and on the other, by providing for a so-called flexibility regime that is structured through the definition of temporal phases and corresponding quantitative work limits.

allowed emissions, provides for the annual release onto the market of a predetermined number of tractors meeting specific characteristics, thus enabling the gradual achievement of the set standards over time without disrupting the affected productive and industrial sectors.

Mr. Tartarella, the work accomplished has been significant and has successfully balanced the needs dictated by the major challenges the European Union is facing at this time with those of environmental protection and the current economic crisis context.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the current global economic crisis, even more severe than that of 1929, has caused unsustainable imbalances in international economies over the past few years.
Trade disparities among countries, financial markets lacking common regulations, and the instability of banking systems are all potential threats to financial and economic stability.
This resolution, to which I express my support, urgently emphasizes the need for a comprehensive reform, new rules, and global economic coordination.

The economy requires a global governance system, open markets, high economic and social standards, more responsible monetary policy, and stricter supervisory policies. International decision-making bodies and economic organizations must be the key actors at the center of this new approach.

Europe, in particular, needs a transparent framework to reduce exaggerated stabilities exacerbated by globalization and to ensure far-reaching reforms aimed at promoting growth and reducing the debt of individual states.
This is the commitment, and this resolution emphasizes it to all countries.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, I have cast a favorable vote for Ms. Mattera's report, which examines the situation of single mothers, who today, as has already been mentioned, account for more than 5% of the European Union's population.

The European Union therefore has a moral obligation to protect them, and the text adopted today supports those policies that can provide concrete help for these women, such as facilitations for women.
healthcare assistance, flexible work opportunities that allow for a balance between private and professional life, priority access from today to affordable prices and special unemployment subsidies.
Only through the implementation of these measures can we address the needs of a category that is increasingly significant in all advanced and industrialized countries.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the budget sets a few clear and important objectives within the framework of the EU 2020 strategy, hence a thank you to the rapporteurs.
It is crucial to focus on investments and not solely on the prudent maintenance of the budget.
The alternative would be to passively witness the speculative philosophy that characterizes our time.
We can no longer afford to pursue individual interests, but must finally represent a single, unified entity ready for dialogue.

I congratulate the commitments made on pilot projects and preparatory actions in heading 2, as well as the funding for the integrated maritime policy not being to the detriment of other initiatives and programs in the fisheries sector.

This will enable us to implement new policies for better management of marine resources through comprehensive research and data exchange on fish stocks, introducing new approaches that can be used as best practices in other marine areas, starting from the Adriatic.

I conclude with a brief note regarding future discussions directed at the ECB, and specifically concerning the fisheries fund, I hope that a greater effort will be made in fisheries control, which is central to combating illegal fishing, but also fundamental for stock reconstruction.
that fish is considered a common good.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the economic, financial, and social crisis we are going through has clearly highlighted several weak points in the European economic and social model.

I believe that one of the most alarming and representative indicators of the current situation is the nearly 6 million jobs lost in the last three years. These figures, unless we can extricate ourselves from this scenario, are set to rise if we fail to respond promptly and effectively.

new financial commitments, new resources, both in the European budget, including within the financial perspectives, and in European policies, as has just been recalled by the Social Fund, the ERDF, and in the budgets of individual states.

Mr. President, the families in distress in our countries, the elderly, the women, the youth, the disabled, and millions of people and families brought to their knees by the crisis and speculation.
Facing this scenario, we are here to discuss plans for supporting the Roma community, housing, and providing for immigrants.
We must focus on assisting those categories that are truly in distress and providing financial and political support to the family, which is the institution upon which our society is founded.
We must support small and medium-sized enterprises hit hard by the crisis, as these SMEs are the real antidote to poverty and the true source of wealth in our countries.
We must prioritize our best resources, not tax them to guarantee a minimum wage for migrants that Europe wants to impose from above.
Enough talk about Roma people and immigrants, now we must prioritize the truly excluded.
If we look around carefully, we will see many of them, and it is certainly not necessary to enter a Roma camp to see them.
The European Union must direct its efforts and funds towards these excluded groups, now more than ever.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, I have cast my vote in favor of the text on the work of the ACP Joint Commission, which, thanks to the quality of its work, has established itself as a key player in cooperation between the North and South of the world.
I myself, as a member of said assembly, participated in the meetings held in Brussels and in the works carried out in Tenerife in April 2010 and in Kinshasa, Congo, in December of the same year.

It is precisely through these visits that I have been able to personally witness, as I did in Angola in 2009, the sad conditions experienced daily by certain peoples, while also assessing the efforts made by the ACP to improve the situation.

In conclusion, I feel compelled to emphasize, especially in this particular historical and political moment, particularly for the countries of North Africa and the Middle East, how the role played by the ACP has been significant.

It is fundamental, especially in the context of supervising negotiations for economic partnership agreements, to promote the transparency of these processes and the development of disadvantaged local communities.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, personally, I find the establishment of a European heritage brand to be an interesting idea.

At a time when, due to the persistent economic crisis, a certain euroskepticism is creeping into many Member States, you believe that an initiative of this kind can strengthen the sense of belonging of European citizens to the Union.

The defining element of the European brand is not, in fact, the beauty of a site, but the symbolic value it has represented or represents for the integration of European citizens in their journey towards improved intercultural dialogue.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, in December 2009, I participated in the COP15 in Copenhagen as an official member of the European Parliament delegation.

Approximately two years have passed, and with regret, I can say that the work done and the commitments made in Copenhagen, later formalized in Cancun, will not be sufficient to achieve the goal of limiting the increase in the annual average temperature of our planet to 2 degrees Celsius.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, we all know how important the role played by the International Criminal Court is, which deals with prosecuting the perpetrators of war crimes, crimes against humanity, and genocide.
Unfortunately, in recent times, the Court has increasingly become the target of unjust political attacks.
Its arrest warrants have often been ignored, and for this reason the current budget is not proportional to the efforts and commitment exerted.

I therefore expressed my vote in favor of the text approved today because it is the task of the European Union to take all political, diplomatic, and logistical actions to support the Court and ensure its independence and proper and effective functioning.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, phosphates present in domestic washing machine detergents end up in water systems, rivers, streams, and European lakes.

Phosphorus causes an acceleration in the reproduction of various forms of life, consequently, algae and other rapidly developing plant species proliferate excessively when there is an increase in phosphorus levels in an aquatic environment.
This excessive algae growth deprives other living organisms of oxygen, can also produce toxins that destroy fish and plant species, thereby reducing the quality of the water itself.

I therefore expressed my vote in favor of the text adopted today, because in order to purify Europe's water resources, it is desirable to reduce the amount of phosphorus that is released into the waters of our continent.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the text presented by colleague Lisek analyzes the possible measures to be implemented to reduce defense costs during a period of severe financial crisis, which is heavily burdening the Community budget.
The main proposals focus on improved coordination of defense system planning, the pooling and sharing of defense capabilities, and support for technological research and development.
I therefore agree with the rapporteur's views that the economic and financial crisis we have been facing can provide an opportunity for integration of the
European Union defense policies, providing the impetus to develop and finally implement those ambitious reforms that have been stalled for years.
For these reasons, I have cast my vote in favor.
Mr. President, a review of European neighborhood policy has become necessary following the Arab Spring and the subsequent events.

It is evident that, given the current state of affairs, relations with the countries in question must be more focused on cooperation, thereby ensuring that democracy and security take priority on both sides of the Mediterranean.

In this regard, I believe that intercultural and interreligious dialogue is fundamental to strengthening mutual respect and tolerance with partner countries in the neighborhood, while also promoting the fight against terrorism and extremism.
For these reasons, Mr. President, I naturally voted in favor.
Mr. President, yesterday in Florence, an event of extreme gravity occurred, one that arouses horror and dismay. A man of great value, a man of great value, a man of great value.
A 50-year-old armed man opened fire on five Senegalese citizens in two markets in the city of Florence. Two of them died, and three are now hospitalized in critical condition.
The murderer then committed suicide.
This is about the racist far-right, former xenophobe, who wanted to kill strangers, guilty only of having black skin.
Florence is my city, and before being elected to the European Parliament, I served as Mayor of Florence for ten years.
Florence is a civil and democratic city, awarded the Gold Medal for its resistance against Nazism and Fascism.
Yet it was in Florence that this abominable racist crime took place, proving that Nazi-fascist madness can manifest anywhere and one must never think it has been definitively erased.
Mr. President, I ask you to express the European Parliament's condolences and to reiterate its commitment against all forms of racism and for the respect and rights of every human being.

in developed countries or in those unaffected by conflicts, with aid clearly hindered also by the unstable security situation.

I also believe that we should no longer proceed in isolated compartments.
Recalling also what Mario Draghi, the Governor of the European Central Bank, said the other day in this very institution, if we also want to push in this sector towards what are the priorities.

For growth and employment, we truly need to be practical and focus primarily on green economy technologies, to genuinely achieve sustainable development and to address the most important needs of our citizens.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, Europe is sinking, stock markets are crashing, the centralist Europe of financial lobbies is disintegrating, but the Danish Presidency opens its semester promising total loyalty to the Commission's plans for the creation of a supranational economic government of the continent.
Instead of focusing on the measures to be implemented to save the destinies of 500 million citizens, the Danish government promises to act as the eurotechnocracy's loyal watchdog in the Council.
I strongly disagree with further steps.
Firstly, I fail to see how one could today propose as a priority the acceleration of the EU's enlargement process towards the Balkan countries.
There are other issues that need to be addressed promptly before concerning oneself with how to integrate the countries in Europe affected by corruption and crime.
And then Turkey, the Danish government strongly pushes for Turkey's accession.
Turkey, fortunately, is far from meeting the parameters set by the EU for entry.

But the true paradox is that, at the very moment the euro is at risk of failure, it should be the Danish Presidency that saves it, Denmark, a country outside the eurozone, because, evidently, it has never trusted the euro.
The rise in intellectual property infringements has reached a high intensity in recent years.
The years risk compromising the strategy on intellectual property rights in the single market launched by the Commission in May 2011.

The main objectives are to raise awareness among public and private sectors about the impact of counterfeiting and piracy, and to inform consumers about the dangers associated with purchasing counterfeit products.
On the basis of the 33 compromise amendments, agreement was reached at first reading on December 19th.

The interconnection of central and commercial registers is indeed an excellent tool to make communications and information retrieval more accessible and, above all, faster for citizens and businesses.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, every time the situation seems to improve, new downgrades by rating agencies come to shake up the performance of international markets.
Numerous European companies are in crisis, and the number of people, especially the young, chronically seeking employment is growing on the job front.
If austerity measures and the defense of the euro are necessary steps, even more so are deep reforms of the labor market at the national level, aimed at revitalizing the European economy.
Only by boosting competitiveness will the European Union instill new confidence in investors and promote the growth of new jobs.
Mr. President, Honorable Bizzotto, I do not deny that the rights of homosexuals need to be protected; what I deny is that there are no homosexual families in Italy.

Homosexuals will never exist, simply because the family that needs to be protected, the one that the European Parliament should also protect, is the traditional family, made up of a woman, a man, and their children.
All of this seems quite elementary to me.
This is the reality in Italy and the other 22 countries.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, first of all, I too would like to associate myself with the warm greeting of colleague Lechner and also with the assessment of his work, which has proceeded with competence, tenacity, and determination.

A laborious task, akin to the work of a Carthusian monk, this draft regulation would sometimes get stuck, and he would bring it back to the table, restarting negotiations with the Council, the Commission, and the Legal Affairs Committee. I believe I can take pride in this aspect.
