In coming to this regulation of ours, I too am convinced that it is an important matter. Perhaps it does not make headlines in the newspapers, perhaps it is not considered high politics, but the construction of the European Union also passes through here.
through satisfying the interests of citizens in their daily lives, and especially those millions and millions who, living across different states, ask us to be represented.
They find themselves facing complex issues that are difficult to untangle, tedious, and sometimes they touch on sensitivities at the heart of a family that politics generally struggles to address.
The European Union should be proud to have such attention at its core.

The solutions that have been proposed are intelligent and innovative. For instance, the person making the will has been given the option to choose between their usual residence or their state of origin.

This makes the decision more flexible, given that there are such profound, truly very profound, differences between one state and another, which could constantly pose challenges to the issue of succession.
However, we have also been given legal certainty, because once the legal choice of absolute residence or habitual residence or country of origin has been made, it cannot be changed.

It determines a limitation on the discretion of judges and also a limitation on the conflicts that may arise, thus providing a more peaceful way to proceed in this field. As a result, there is more freedom and greater certainty.

And then the certificate of inheritance, here we believe that certificates are a matter of little importance, this creates the conditions under which the heir has a more manageable and certain position with regard to all the possible difficulties that might arise for him.
It is a fact that characterizes this law positively.

And it is true, this law is not perfect; there are issues concerning the executor, the practicality of direct inheritance, and so forth. However, I do not want to only utter one more word of a political nature.
We hope that the Council approves this text, we hope it becomes a regulation, but we must not seal its fate, as we cannot remain idle within the European Union either.
England is in a different situation with Great Britain, as Europe cannot do without Great Britain, so we should proceed to overcome these difficulties subsequently.
Thank you, sir.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the European Union has produced an enormous quantity of laws and regulations to construct European law and has created the European area, known as the Stockholm Plan.
There is a discrepancy between this corpus, this legislative monument, and the use made of it by citizens, which is numerically and proportionally very low.
On the other hand, national judges, the legal professionals of individual states, have grown up within the legal system of their own country and have received predominant training in this field.
This is the essence, as we believe that the true European judge is the national judge who changes their mindset and immerses themselves in the knowledge of European law.

For this reason, before discussing training, one must first address a comprehensive communication to citizens and legal professionals, so that they can become the bearers of this significant innovation and foster the willingness to utilize the benefits of this right.

But then, above all, it is a bottom-up movement that must be created in in-service training. Lessons cannot be taught as if to schoolchildren in the judicial training of adult and highly professionally qualified individuals.

One must foster curiosity in addressing one's own cases, in connecting with other colleagues, and in finding solutions, given that today common law and civil law converge, and are no longer as distant as they once were within the legal culture.

This is the crux of our proposals, and I am pleased that the European Commission has been persuaded of these aspects. In our view, we are calling for a change in approach, with more legal studies and less judicial training.
There is an example in the Netherlands called Eurinfra, which is very interesting. It is a network of coordinators in each court who disseminate this knowledge and encourage judges in this regard.
Here, the essence of our project is this: we hope it will receive the full support of the Commission.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, I would like to express, first of all, my very sincere appreciation for the work done by colleague Giegold with this initiative report. I also recall that together with him and others, we share an active presence in the social economy intergroup of this Parliament.

My political group, as you know, believes that the social model is one of the founding characteristics of the European integration project, not just one of many policies, but a policy that defines our project itself.

And in these times, with attacks also linked to necessities, public spending cuts, and so on, we still defend this conviction, this priority. We know that it can be an updated, modified social model, but we also believe that it should be maintained, defended, and reaffirmed precisely as a priority.

Therefore, I believe that, within this same perspective, we must also enhance economic entities that engage in business, that produce goods and services, such as cooperatives, which play a very specific role in the so-called European social economy.

They reiterate that production is possible, that good things can be done, and that efficiency can be achieved, even if profit is not the goal. Instead, for example, the objectives might be employment, welfare, the valorization of labor, and contributing to the life of the local community.

This is why, Mr. President, I conclude that it is important for Europe to provide the necessary tools for an active policy and to create a good statute, not the current inadequate one, but a well-crafted statute for cooperatives can be a way to support this crucial sector.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the role of the cooperative movement has always been significant in building a more balanced and fair economic dimension.

This is a time of great change, and in this moment when we are experiencing one of the most severe economic and social crises since the postwar period, the role of cooperative societies becomes crucial.

there has been a robust development of the cooperative dimension in the economy, there has consequently been an increase in employment, more qualified jobs, and a more balanced redistribution of the wealth produced.
It is therefore positive that the European Union has adopted a statute for cooperative societies, but now more than ever it is necessary that there be a real simplification of the rules.
We need to give new impetus to the creation of a common European framework in the field of cooperation, and this must be done by helping and not creating bureaucratic obstacles.
For this reason, I voted in favor of this resolution and hope that the Commission and the Council will actively work to address the issues mentioned.

The salvation of Europe's millions of unemployed does not depend on the faltering aid offered by the European Fund for Integration. The data collected highlights that most beneficiaries of the Fund are unable to find new employment, while the more fortunate are reintegrated into the labor market with fixed-term contracts, sometimes as short as six months.
In many cases, unemployed individuals give up on this fund because they doubt its usefulness.
The FEG is not a solution and does not mitigate the disastrous consequences of a European trade policy managed dangerously and too lightly by the Commission.

To combat the scourge of now structural unemployment, Europe must curb its excessive openness to the markets of developing countries, whose real competition is the primary cause of the failures of our businesses.
Until Europe stops promoting economic self-harm by maintaining a short-sighted stance towards global trade flows, our businesses will continue to fail.
The fund can only provide temporary support, but it is not through training courses that our unemployed will find serenity and security.
I believe that this is a significant achievement for the European Parliament today, as what Attila, the President of the Commission, wrote on July 15th has proven to be a great success.

President Buzek, in stating that we must establish an anti-Mafia commission, I recall that there were many colleagues from various countries who said, "But the Mafia is a problem of Sicily and Italy."

Today, the recognition by colleagues from the north of all Europe that there is a problem of organized crime in Europe and the will to fight together against it, I believe, is a great and important fact, and I want to say thank you, President, thank you to the whole Parliament.
Mr. President, thank you to Mr. Sondahl for the comprehensive presentation, which led to an extensive discussion.

I too would like to firstly reiterate my solidarity with the families of the victims of the serious clashes that took place in Zanzibar on December 16, as well as our concern for the subsequent development of events.

What began as a union warning degenerated into the most serious incidents, in which 17 people lost their lives, and in the days following the incidents, into the arrest of journalists and opposition representatives.

It is in the interest of all, and as Kazakhstan has demonstrated firsthand, to shed full light on the events. I hope, therefore, that today's session will be remembered solely as a positive opportunity for our Parliament to delve deeper into what has transpired thus far.

and reiterate our call for an investigation that assures the international community that responsibilities for the events in San Jos will be clarified and those responsible will be prosecuted with the utmost respect for the principles of legality and protection of human rights.

The delegation, with the honor of presiding, had the opportunity, during some of its meetings, to listen to the explanations provided by the Kazakh authorities and also by some NGOs very active in observing events in this country.
The willingness of the Kazakhstani authorities to provide explanations, as well as their promises of further clarifications, are undoubtedly positive elements that we all, of course, appreciate.

For this reason as well, I would like to stress the need to maintain a certain balance, a balance that I had hoped to see highlighted in the text of the resolution that we will vote on tomorrow, which in my view is very important.

In my opinion, it would perhaps have been appropriate to postpone the decision until the conclusion of the official investigations, which would have benefited from the support of an official mission from international organizations.

The undeniable need for further clarity on what occurred and the requirement to urge Kazakhstan to make ever-greater efforts to improve progress towards democracy must also be constantly accompanied by a renewed commitment and an open and constructive dialogue with this country.

Mr. President, I voted in favor of this proposal as it aims to update the 2004 regulations to adapt to changes in the national legislation of Member States concerning social security and to keep pace with changes in social reality that impact the coordination of these security systems themselves.

This proposal also incorporates suggestions from the administrative commission for the coordination of security systems, with the aim of improving, modernizing, and achieving compliance in accordance with Article 72(f) of the previous regulations.

The amendments contained in this proposal are designed to ensure legal certainty for the parties concerned. Moreover, they aim to guarantee appropriate coordination at the European Union level of national social security systems.

It also reflects the regulatory changes at the national level, and it was necessary to approve it as it takes into account recent developments in cross-border mobility that impact the coordination of social security systems.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the credibility of the European Union at the international level and the effectiveness of its policies on human rights undoubtedly depend on the condemnation of violations, abuses, and human rights infringements.

But it is also of utmost importance to prevent gender disparities among citizens and communities, discrimination, crimes committed in situations other than armed conflicts, the lack of respect for women, minors, and the most vulnerable in general, as well as persecutions based on religion or belief.

between the European Union's human rights policy and other external policies, thus promoting democratization and supporting the fight against social inequalities, especially in times of economic crisis such as the current one.
Mr. President, I would like to thank colleagues Arsenis, Patro Neves, Romeva, and their assistants for their substantial contributions to the success of this initiative.
Fish is a common good, as it provides 15% of the protein intake for over 3 billion people, and the livelihoods of over 500 million depend on fisheries and aquaculture.
This makes it a true global public good.
The approval of this statement provides the Commission with a clear direction on the need to promote responsible behavior, both within fishing communities and among consumer habits.

The debate on reforming the common fisheries policy now has an additional reason to support actions that move European policy beyond the narrow focus on resource extraction methods and a set of rules that are solely inward-looking.

On the contrary, a maritime strategy is suggested as a privileged means to increase its reproductive capacity, both in inland waters and through innovative modalities of fisheries agreements with third countries.

Moreover, this is not just about environmental protection and preserving biodiversity, but also responsible fishing, economic and social sustainability, and the very interests of fishermen and our economies.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the third amendment to the regulation,
1083, presented by the European Commission in a short time, contains provisions aimed at creating a European risk-sharing instrument.

The goal is in fact to address the difficulties encountered by some Member States in raising the private financing needed for the implementation of investment projects that can only be partially funded through the use of public funds.

Although the path to exiting the economic crisis is still long, I consider the work done to reach a compromise text that set a maximum for the funds allocated to the financial instrument and better defined the risk-sharing tools to be fruitful.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the economic crisis, technological development, and demographic changes have transformed European society and the labor market in recent years.
To meet future skill demands, many people will need to complete higher education, and many workers will have to continuously update their skills and knowledge while already employed.

For this reason, I express my vote in favor of the text by colleague Toques, which aims at modernizing higher education systems to achieve the objectives set by the Europe 2020 strategy and promote social, cultural, and economic development within the Union.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, I will not dwell at length, as in this short time I wish only to touch upon a few points.

I believe that this seventh environmental action program can certainly be a useful tool, but only if it is based on a vision of the future that takes into account the need to maintain a strong European industrial base, which is essential for maintaining a decent and acceptable level of employment.
There are things that concern me.
I believe that an absolute priority is for this program to ensure the most effective implementation of the regulation already in place before setting new goals.

I am deeply convinced that, in order to tackle today's environmental challenges, we must rely on future environmental policies that are based on robust evidence, the most up-to-date scientific knowledge, and the most advanced scientific expertise.

I am concerned about Article 24, which discusses the ecological footprint as an absolute indicator. It represents an empirical indicator and model of reality, not reality itself, and this must be kept in mind.

This has many limitations; it tells us how much we impact the environment, but it absolutely does not estimate, for example, the quality of the environment. Therefore, my concerns remain, and I invite everyone to take this into account.
When we speak of good examples for citizens, we must consider the internal market and the possibilities it offers to create opportunities for European citizens.

We have authentic and concrete opportunities for change in our daily lives through the internal market; we can truly leverage this example, and we will undoubtedly need many others as a result of our work.
It is a good example because, as mentioned, it impacts the concrete lives of citizens, and daily life also helps businesses expand their market, not because costs are high and services are poor.
So I believe it is undoubtedly a positive example, a good example, because it is a sector of fundamental importance to the economy, a sector of fundamental importance to the economy.

However, you will have understood, Commissioner, that there is a widely shared will in this Parliament, I particularly refer to the contributions of two of my colleagues, Mardurel Goebbels and my group, but also many others.
There are others who would like this good example to become excellent and for us to move forward, and to some extent this measure provides for a zero-roaming result, because it is possible.
We are utopians.

No, because a European internal market entails that tariffs be similar between domestic and non-domestic entities, there is no longer a distinction when discussing a single market, and primarily because there is no technical justification for increased costs.
I remember when, in 2007, we started talking about voice roaming, the first third-party roaming we were part of.
There was a certain incredulity and also a certain difficulty, not on the part of the CommissionI must give credit to its predecessor, Commissioner Reding.

Difficulties were widespread, coming from those who argued that a true market position does not entail tariff regulation; they are political prices, belonging to an old conception of the left, and so on. There were also those who said it wouldn't work, that it would curb the market, but in the end, we did it.
The realization that there were no such technical justifications for the increase in costs led to taking a step forward.
So the world moves forward, things become increasingly, let's say, possible. For this reason, I believe an even bolder outcome is achievable.
Final observation, as no further ones are possible today: we have had a delegation of Tunisian citizens, I don't know if they are still present.
Among the many benefits, this extra-EU expansion perhaps makes us realize that the ability to use, without the real fear of costs, also fosters democracy.
In Europe, there are more than 120 million broadband users, with at least 70 million citizens using their mobile devices to connect to the internet, work, study, or simply stay informed.
Thanks to this regulation, the European Union has finally decided to intervene on behalf of all these consumers, reducing the cost of international voice, data, and SMS phone traffic.
A positive decision because the price reduction program will lead to an average decrease in rates of 35% over the next three years.

However, this is not enough in a challenging moment like the present one. From an economic and employment perspective, communication, new technologies, and innovation are essential goods that Europe must defend with greater courage.
Every European citizen should be able to move freely between Member States, benefiting from the telephone tariff established by their national operator.

No more fraud and exorbitant bills for those traveling within the EU. If we truly want to provide a concrete response to citizens, let's create a kind of Schengen area for telecommunications, which no longer imposes different rates on citizens based on the countries in which they operate.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, I was part of that delegation from the European Parliament that visited Sicily last November.
Our delegation leader, Cecilia Wistrom, wrote a letter to the Italian minister, the Minister of the Interior, and received a response that provided us with rather clear answers.

I want to recall above all the fact that after that visit to Italy the government changed, and the approach to the situation also changed, but even the situation itself in the countries from which the migratory flow predominantly originated changed.
However, this should not exempt us from the necessity of a careful analysis of what has happened and also of the current situation.
The most significant fact that remains relevant to this day is Lampedusa's status as a non-safe port, the closure of the first aid and reception center in Contrada Imbriagola following the fire of

The first was the disaster of 2011 which damaged it, but only partially, namely one dormitory destroyed, one damaged out of seven buildings in the structure, and then the de facto suppression of the project.

Now consider that the only unsafe port in the Mediterranean was Tripoli during Gaddafi's time, and I do not find this analogy flattering, given that migratory flows, although significantly reduced in number, even for seasonal reasons, are still growing.

They have certainly not stopped. It is crucial that a first aid and reception operation functions effectively on Lampedusa, as it is the first port of call for those arriving from the other side after journeys that are by no means easy or risk-free, as the Somali shipwreck survivors who reached Lampedusa well know.

in the month of April this year, after witnessing the deaths of 10 people on the large boat they were traveling on, or the 20 who were transferred from Linosa because there was no space in other reception centers, or the 18 who still live in Linosa in the stadium changing rooms.

The tourist residence of Cala Creta, where they are currently accommodated, is certainly not a CIE (Identification and Expulsion Center) or a detention center, and above all, in the meantime, both the healthcare system and the possibility of requesting asylum have been dismantled in Lampedusa.
Everything relies on the goodwill and kind-heartedness of the carabiniers on duty, or the citizens and volunteers of Lampedusa.
Another consideration to be made is the function that the center itself had assumed in the recent past.

Allowing, against every legal and ethical norm, thousands upon thousands of people to gather in a place that, due to its capacity and the function it was intended for, could only accommodate a few hundred.

Allowing a small territory of a few square kilometers, already challenging due to its location and logistical difficulties, to be forced to accommodate a number of people greater than its own population must have done the rest.
We must reflect on the responsibilities for an extremely tense situation.
It is not possible to be arrested within the fire itself.
I believe that the excellent report by colleague Rinaldi was successful in the Chamber.
I fully share the flattering assessment of the report.

Nevertheless, I would like to raise a small issue: our Europe, with regard to this new world that is striving for democracy and different economic conditions, is a Europe divided by the Mediterranean.

It is a particular focus on the Mediterranean that I would like the Commission to direct its attention to, both in terms of environmental aspects and in terms of the economic transactions that take place in the Mediterranean.
Nedran is a fishing spot.
We are constructing a new fisheries policy in Europe, which will establish very strict rules on Europe's behalf.
On the other hand, there are no rules instead.
So why not use fisheries agreement frameworks, providing support to these countries so that they can implement the same rules that are applied in Europe?

This would be beneficial for European fisheries, for the sea, for environmental conservation, to ensure that this divided region becomes less fragmented and increasingly homogeneous, thus providing a foundation for building the future of Europe and this new world.

With the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon, the European Parliament has become a fully-fledged institutional actor in the field of security policies and, as such, has the right to actively and determinantly participate in the priorities of the internal security strategy and the Union's security model.

The report by colleague Borsellino identifies five key sectors for which concrete actions have been proposed and calls for enhanced judicial and police cooperation among Member States to tackle organized crime and terrorism.
I believe it is of particular importance to strongly consider the development of prevention policies, which are fundamental tools to ensure a space of European freedom, security, and justice.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, with the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon, the foundations have been laid for the development of integrated criminal law within Community law.

Affirming the importance of mutual recognition, the harmonization of protection rules, and the principle of presumption of innocence, it is essential to emphasize that the law should be of utmost clarity and easily understandable, so as to make it clear to everyone which actions constitute a crime and which do not.
This is particularly true for directives that must be reciprocal in national law.
Any lack of charity could, in part, give rise to divergent interpretations of the law.

I therefore believe that only close cooperation between European institutions on the principles and methods to be followed can ensure a coherent and high-quality European strategy in the field of criminal law.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the European Union safeguards the general interests of consumers against unfair business practices, deceptive advertising, and abusive contractual clauses, but there is no solution.
It is questionable whether those consumers who are most vulnerable due to age, physical or mental health issues, or simply a lack of proper information, should be protected with greater care.
I therefore expressed my favorable vote for the text presented by colleague Perez, as I agree that the creation of a strategy for consumer law is essential.
of the so-called most vulnerable contributes not only to their social inclusion, but also to ensuring a safer, fairer, and more competitive single market.
The report by colleague Perez, for which we have expressed our favorable vote, focuses on the need to consider the preparation of a report for the future.

A strategy is aimed at protecting the rights of the most vulnerable consumers, in anticipation of the strategy that the European Commission and the Member States will be called upon to develop in this regard.
Consumer vulnerability stems from various causes and potentially affects everyone.

For this reason, it is necessary to provide protection for this category alongside that of the general consumer and to develop a targeted strategy in this regard, which, in considering the multifaceted nature of the problem, avoids

On the one hand, the formulation of static and rigid definitions that are unable to consider all the nuances of the issue and the various possible forms of vulnerability, and on the other, it wards off the creation of new types of discrimination.
It is therefore necessary to arrive at the definition of specific and targeted protection measures.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the management of bluefin tuna fishing has a long and rather complex history dating back to the 1990s, and to this day, it is likely the most strictly regulated by the European Union.
Despite significant investments in control measures leading to increased compliance with regulations, there are still concerns regarding the issue of overfishing.
I have therefore expressed my support for the Romeva i Rueda report, which proposes a reduction in the allowable catch rate, increased control, and strengthened capacity reduction measures.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the relations between the European Union and China clearly reveal imbalances at the commercial level.
It is therefore the duty of European institutions to strive to help European businesses emerge from the crisis and achieve fairer access to international markets.
I therefore expressed my support for this report, sharing in particular, among the issues highlighted by the rapporteur, the application of the principle of reciprocity to relations.
the relations between the European Union and China to allow fair competition in international markets and the demand for greater protection of intellectual property rights.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the road is still long, but today's step can be a significant one towards the long-awaited introduction and implementation of a financial transactions tax.
I understand the prudence, the caution, and the need for a gradual approach expressed by Commissioner Schmetta, as well as the technical issues rightly raised by Minister Vestager.

But for this very reason, I hope that Parliament will express a clear political will, with a large majority, to provide impetus and momentum for the initiatives needed to tackle the problems that remain unresolved, especially at Council level.
We all want to carefully assess the impact of this tax, but it is not right to stir up unfounded fears, which can also lead to contradictory and counterproductive choices.
I am referring, for example, to the logic of the proposal for exemptions.
If one is attentive to reducing the tax's impact, it is important to have the widest possible tax base, with a low rate, and not to attempt to extend exemptions indefinitely.

To those concerned about the impact on small investors, I remind them of the progressive nature of the tax, which means that those who carry out more transactions and investments are taxed more heavily.
of transactions, and it is clear that the competent authorities must in any case ensure that any costs are not passed on to customers and end users.
I therefore hope that Parliament will vote by a large majority in favor of this tax.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, since 1990, through the instrument of macro-financial assistance, the European Union has been providing economic aid in the form of grants, loans, or a combination of both to countries experiencing short-term balance of payments difficulties.
The rather lengthy timelines, combined with the difficulties posed by the decision-making criteria used so far, have made it necessary to formulate some amendments to the regulations.

I therefore welcome the proposal introduced in the new regulation, which aims to make the evaluation criteria faster and more effective, and to agree on clearer rules and conditions for the provision of macro-financial assistance.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, there are approximately 100 million European citizens engaged in various volunteering activities.

From major sporting events to cultural gatherings, the role played by volunteers is crucial. Equally important is the work of those who rush to offer aid and solidarity in the event of severe natural or environmental disasters.
Volunteering constitutes one of the broadest expressions of active citizenship and a crucial activity for the development of democratic values and equality within the European Union.
For this reason, I advocate the development of high-quality volunteering, both national and cross-border, and the elimination of the obstacles currently in place.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, from the communications sector to finance, transportation, energy, from culture to health, the role played by technology is becoming increasingly significant.
The increasingly frequent use of the Internet and digital tools makes the issue of cybersecurity one of the priorities on the European agenda.

Information and communication technologies can indeed promote economic and social development only if the regulations in force ensure user safety regarding data privacy and intellectual property rights.

Only through full international cooperation involving member states, institutions, and industries in the sector can a robust system be created that is capable of implementing effective measures to ensure cybersecurity.
Madam President, thanks to the Commissioner, she has said important, commendable things that are of great significance.
I find it truly, as he said, staggering that we have each lived in our own countries with the numbers and figures we heard earlier from colleague Oconio.
2020. But it is equally evident that this scandal has truly highlighted the need for a thorough assessment of the European legislation currently in force on medical devices.

Unfortunately, this fraud has highlighted the gaps we have been discussing in the classroom up to now, which the Commissioner has so ably represented. Therefore, I do not wish to dwell on this aspect in the short time I have available.
I believe it is essential to deploy all the necessary resources to ensure we can offer the best to our citizens.
But I believe that this scandal, which has taught us so many things, could also be an opportunity to take a further step forward, and I build on what the colleague said before.

The communication directed at patients is truly subpar; it always emphasizes only the positive aspects, speaking of a sort of eternal youth and promised beauty. There are no prostheses that are absolutely risk-free.

I believe that this awareness, especially when it comes to pure cosmetic surgery, should truly be communicated to people, to young women, because we know that there are very young girls considering this type of procedure.
So I see that you are absent-minded, so I urge you, let's really get to work, time is tight, we should have already done this yesterday.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the Council regulation concerning the multi-annual plan for the stock of herring was adopted prior to the entry into force of the treaty, and thus an alignment has become necessary.

This regulation, the first in the fisheries sector to be aligned with the treaty, is therefore of considerable importance, as the solution adopted in this case could impact the decision-making procedure applicable to other multiannual plans.
For this reason, I express my vote in favor.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, from Seveso to Bhopal to Toulouse, there have been numerous environmental disasters in recent years that have struck Europe and endangered the health of European citizens.

Colleague Ader's text concerns the revision of the SES II directive, which aims to contain the effects of incidents involving significant quantities of dangerous and highly polluting substances released into the environment.

The revised regulations, which will come into force from June 2015, are aimed at protecting the environment and above all at limiting tragic health consequences for citizens. Therefore, I expressed my vote in favor.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, I too would like to thank Stevenson for his excellent work and the approach he has taken in this report, which essentially addresses the two main issues.

This is not merely about a plan for managing herring; it is fundamentally about ensuring a future for fishermen in certain respects and planning for the sea to ensure that it has its protections over multiple years.
But the key point of this relationship is, and remains, the issue of delegated acts.

I believe that the Council should accept the approach set out in the Treaty of Lisbon, and I also think that it is high time for the Parliament, in some way, to speak with a voice that is perhaps more authoritative than that of the European Parliament.
in a debate within the fisheries committee or in a debate on a report concerning herring, have the courage to take a very clear and strong stance on the issue of delegated acts.
We claim the right for ordinary procedure to truly be in place on these matters.

I am fully aware that the issue involves, in addition to many other sectors of fishing, areas that will worsen in relation to the ongoing reform, but it also concerns matters related to agriculture and other topics.
The essential aspect is respecting the will of Parliament.
In drafting this report, no account was taken of the directly concerned parties, the road haulage companies.
In Italy, 91% of freight transport takes place by road.
Their rights will be ignored if this report is approved in its current form.
In many committees of this Parliament, we work daily to reduce the financial and administrative burden on our businesses, but reports like this undermine our efforts.
We must make every effort, as these measures will suffocate businesses with new bureaucratic burdens, devastating economic losses, and new forms of unfair competition.

Only a little effort would have been needed to achieve a balanced agreement that did not overlook the survival rights of our businesses during a very challenging economic period, but this kind of dialogue was not possible.

On the contrary, the report deliberately ignored even previous legislative acts of the European Union, such as the 2002 directive on working time, and even ignored documents from the European Commission recognizing the dangers of practices such as retrofitting, which are instead proposed again in this report.
The document we will be voting on tomorrow, colleagues, will ask you to forget the positive achievements made in recent years, and once again, European businesses will bear the cost.
Just to say, Mr. President, that ACTA was a grave political mistake, setting aside the legal aspects, it elicited a massive global reaction, and that alone is enough to declare it a political error.
But why the Bense?
Because it created the suspicion that access to the web was truly being closed off, which is a great modern revolution.
And why is this?
Why did you make the mistake of conflating counterfeiting and piracy, which are two distinctly separate phenomena?
The way to combat counterfeiting has nothing to do with copyright.
And then there is another mistake, which has excluded Parliament from an important activity it has been carrying out for some time, which is the creation of a new copyright, a new author's right.

The old copyright that existed before the web. The point is that we need to work on copyright and set aside ACTA, which is an obstacle, and reject and exclude it, because it is an obstacle to our work.

Fortunately, the Commission, after months and years of hesitation, has brought two important measuresone on orphan works and the next on copyright management societiesto the attention of the Parliament.
So, but let's work on this by reflecting with our minds and not just with emotion, but without obstacles in our path.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, I merely wish to add my voice to the praise this report has received in this Chamber regarding the need to strengthen the European Union's capacity to address the challenges of the future.
to be a place where it is possible to invest, produce, and create from the perspective of our conception of an inclusive economy, socially and environmentally sustainable.

So I believe that some guidelines here in this measure are very useful, others can be added, and I think it is important to gather this suggestion, to work more and more so that attractiveness is the main focus.
as a consequence of territorial policies, territorial marketing, and openness, which on the part of the territory amounts to the proposal of a productive, industrial vocation.

that originates from the territory respects all environmental compatibilities and at the same time aligns with European policies in this direction, a voice from the territory and Europe that is attractive for investments and growth.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, when discussing sensitive issues such as the authorization of products and substances for use in organic productions, we are addressing the protection of European citizens' health.

It is indeed important to meet consumer expectations regarding the quality of organic products circulating in European markets, and it is equally important to ensure the proper application of Community regulations by the authorities, bodies, and operators concerned.
For this reason, I express my favorable vote for the colleague's text.
Focusing on the initial comments about the Council, the phase of reductive reading has now begun, and this is mistaken, because significant steps forward have been taken.
Consider, for example, the breaking of the destructive ties between banks and public debt, and the still fragile plan for employment and work.

It seems that the spirit of renewal and a renewed path towards political unity is once again emerging within European institutions, after a long period of slowness, torpor, and a desire for real progress towards greater integration.
We have witnessed a strong unity between Parliament and the Commission on this matter.

I am not referring to winners and losers, but it is undeniable that there has been a new institutional and political vitality compared to the past diarchy, which was the very negation, the antithesis of the communal spirit.
There has been an initiative and activism from multiple countries, not to create new exclusive axes, but to build a common and respectful consensus among all member states.
This is the path towards the political goal of unity, without which any banking, fiscal, and monetary union will be entirely insufficient.
On June 6, with the Council's decision to return to member states the possibility of reinstating border controls, a new Europe was born, a brave Europe in fulfilling the desire of all.
and greater security for its citizens, is finally inspired by a more mature interpretation of the concept of solidarity, brought back to the defense of the rights of its peoples above all.

To President Schulz, even though he is not present, I say that this historic decision does not represent an interinstitutional incident, but rather a respect for the will of the citizens, not that of the Eurocracy which for years has pretended not to understand what is really happening outside the glass palace.
No imaginary influx of clandestines, Mr. President Schulz, but a measured increase in illegal immigrants, as recorded by Frontex, of 35% in 2011.

I only regret that the scenes of political sterility played out in this Chamber and at the last plenary session have stolen time from more useful and constructive activities, leading us to question why it was not we who defended the interests of our citizens, but the Member States.

If the Parliament does not find its soul and the courage to stand against goodism, the sterile obviousness upon which it has been balancing for too long, it will continue to be a follower and not a leader in the construction of the European project.
I would like to draw the attention of this Assembly to the fact that yesterday, it was a...
We have officially announced that the Higgs boson has been measured and definitively detected.
the particle that gives mass to all others and their existence, and this occurred on European soil.
Science gives life to our planet, civilization, and well-being, and for a moment we can aspire to become once again a capital of world science.
Utopia is the characteristic of man who invents a utopia and wants to realize it, and it is for science and this wonderful ambition of man that today a person
A blind person who does not have eyes can see with their hands or read a book with their ears, and a young South African boy who has no legs can run in the Olympics in a sprint competition.
Well, Europe must be the home of science, this great event that will open new frontiers of knowledge must be supported through and through by Europe.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, all too often within the European Union, crime victims do not file reports due to fear or lack of trust in institutions.
The text voted on today aims to strengthen the rights of victims of crime and to ensure them the same level of protection, assistance, and access to justice under safe conditions.
all the countries of the Union, paying particular attention to those victims who are at high risk of suffering further harm or intimidation during the criminal proceedings.

Of particular importance, therefore, is the recognition of victim status not only for individuals who have suffered harm as a result of a crime, but also for their family members and the deceased person as a consequence of the crime.
On September 11th, the Catalan people peacefully demonstrated in Barcelona.
One million people demanded the independence of Catalonia from Spain.
On October 15th of last year, British Prime Minister Cameron signed the agreement to allow the referendum for Scotland's independence from London.
In Veneto, my region, in recent weeks, thousands of people have signed to hold a referendum for independence from Veneto and Italy.
Yesterday, in Veneto, Lombardy, and all the northern regions, hundreds and thousands of people signed for greater autonomy from Rome.
But also in Flanders, in the Basque Country, citizens are loudly demanding autonomy and independence from nation-states.
What does President Schulz say?
It calls for a courageous commitment to clearly say no to all separatist tendencies.
His deputy, Vidal Quadra, went even further, advocating the use of force against Catalan citizens.
Their statements are an extremely serious act, contrary to the principles of the very democracy that we preach here and that we must defend.
I tell them that it will be the peoples who will write the future of the new Europe, not the bureaucrats of Brussels.
The path is already laid out.
The rigor policy adopted to exit the economic crisis did not yield the expected results.
as highlighted in the report by colleague La Via, by investing more selectively and supporting the ideal of a European budget that is sometimes too constrained.
To support growth and employment, it will be possible to rebalance the economies of the Member States, improving the situation of European citizens.
For this reason, I have therefore expressed my favorable vote.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the social and economic context in which the multiannual financial framework for the period 2014 is being discussed is rather problematic.

With Member States committed to making fiscal adjustments to their national budgets to balance public finances, the European Union is seen in some cases as an entity that increases the financial burden on taxpayers.

For this reason, to truly overcome the crisis and ensure a better future for European youth, it will be of fundamental importance to support greater and more tangible investments in the sectors of education and development.
This is the programmatic document of an institution; its budget reveals what it is, what it does, and above all, what it intends to do in the future.

We are faced with a crucial choice between a survival budget, a budget of mere continuity, perhaps with everyone having a little less, or a budget of courage, of selective choices, of investments in employment, innovation, and youthin other words, in the future of the European Union and its development vocation.

Everyone should understand that, as colleague Calfin has stated very clearly, Europe can do today what the States can no longer do for the economy, for regional development, for the territories where social cohesion is established or where it destroys the lives of the citizens we have discussed.
Major European decisions risk being suffocated today by accounting-related disputes within the Council, but not only between beneficiary countries, payer countries, and contributing countries.

We argue that this is a false dilemma, because it is easy to demonstrate with figures, with numbers, not with words, based on past experience, that contributing countries, sometimes more than others, benefit from economic convergence and growth.
The Council is currently working to assign figures to the various budget lines.

The war of positions has begun, with declarations and stances taken by certain states that view the budget as following any expense item, which can be cut without remorse, indeed, perhaps even useful in comforting an anti-European sentiment that is easy to stir in times of economic crisis.
It is a mistaken position that does not aid the integration we are striving for in other areas.
Dear colleagues, our Europe is still incomplete and mutilated, many of us have said so.
We have adopted a stability pact, which was also meant to be for development, but we have become so stabilized that we are in recession.
Here, let us seize at least the opportunity of this budget, of this multiannual framework, to make choices in the right direction.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the lack of information and awareness about one's rights, coupled with economic barriers, is not a solution.
Language barriers and the non-recognition of diplomas and qualifications are the most common problems faced by Union citizens when residing, studying, or working in another European Union country.
Unfortunately, there is still a lack of visibility regarding the notion of European citizenship and its tangible benefits.
For this reason, I have expressed my support for 2013 as the European Year of Citizens.

The primary objective is indeed to enhance awareness of the rights associated with Union citizenship and to assist citizens in fully exercising their right to move and reside freely within the territories of the Member States.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the proliferation of innovative financial instruments presents numerous challenges in terms of regulation, governance, and monitoring their effectiveness.
Indeed, it is necessary to find a fair balance between the objectives of transparency and control, as well as a sufficient level of effectiveness and speed of implementation.

The introduction of such instruments at the European level is nevertheless of great importance, as it represents a means by which the European Union, especially in times of crisis, can stimulate investments in the economy.
realistically, in line with its objectives, in a context where the continuous decrease in contributions to the EU budget is at odds with the constant growth of its political ambitions.
Brussels I Regulation has undoubtedly been one of the most effective acts of European regulation for occupational health and safety.
of Union legislation, as it has outlined the foundations of a European judicial space, promoting and ensuring legal certainty among European citizens.
The dissemination of such regulation addresses fundamental issues for the development of European justice, including the extension of rules on
on the jurisdiction over disputes involving parties domiciled in third countries and agreements regarding the choice of the competent court.

I am convinced that the adoption of the new regulation can ensure stronger consumer protection and greater legal certainty within the internal market, and for this reason, I have cast my vote in favor.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, today Europe is being called upon to undertake a new task of coordinating industrial policies, and even the most staunch proponents of autonomy and private initiative are now calling for the exercise of this role.
Without a greater Europeanization of national strategies, also in terms of job protection, the current crisis cannot be overcome and there will be no recovery.
The automotive crisis is not merely excess production capacity; it is a dramatic loss of employment.
But the crisis now appears structural and concerns the very destiny of the automobile, of the product, as we know it today.
We want to keep the automotive industry in Europe and we aim to preserve the existing skills and know-how, the professional expertise.
We therefore request that a major restructuring and revitalization project be initiated and implemented within a short timeframe, as costs are proportional to time.
Restructuring cannot be solely the result of fragmented national decisions or individual company initiatives.
It is necessary at least to attempt to coordinate and guide this painful process at the community level, bringing together the stakeholders through social dialogue.
producers, labor unions, and the governments of individual countries, offering support through research, innovation, human capital training, retraining, and necessary funding.
I know this will be a challenging task, as the national interests of individual companies are not aligned.

But since the competitive clash underway in the European Union is very ambiguous and sometimes risks being unfair, I believe that in the end it is in the interest of all countries to have an effective community impulse and guidance to jointly face the increasingly aggressive global market.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the energy crisis has exacted and continues to exact a very high price from all employment sectors, affecting thousands of precarious, stable, and temporary workers, who are numerous in this industry.
The major steel groups are increasingly turning towards the Far East or the American continent, posing a great question about the direction of our development model.
I believe that Europe must reclaim the idea that a manufacturing system like ours requires robust core productions capable of supplying the European internal market.
We must therefore defend this sector, the role of a stable steel industry, and we will support it, Commissioner, if we want to halt industrial decline.

I believe we need to move away from a dualism that has not been fully explored here tonight, but which is often felt in discussions on this sectora dualism between environmentalists and workers' advocates. This is mistaken because it does not allow us to see a future perspective.
An industry that considers steelmaking as an integral part requires advanced production systems, concrete and balanced solutions that safeguard the various interests and different needs.

Therefore, a strong planning approach is needed, also at the European level, with a focus on sustainability, from which we must not retreat, in my opinion, as it represents a true added value with which we aim to compete globally, by supporting investments.

We have spoken extensively about new technologies, new processes, and the upgrading of facilities for a European economy that makes effective use of resources, including energy resources, in fact starting with energy resources and also focusing on the research of new and different materials.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, as we have recalled in this Chamber, next December, the United Nations agency dedicated to communication and information technologies will meet in Dubai for the World Conference on International Communications.
The subject is the renegotiation of international telecommunications regulations.

We cannot forget, I am pleased with Commissioner Tajani's words, the work that has been done so far, which cannot be called into question, nor can we allow the authority of the European Union to be bypassed.

a supranational structure like the ITU, of which we know that hundreds of states from around the world are part, and many of which are known for issues related to democracy, transparency, and freedom of expression.
Therefore, it is not incorrect to believe that the pillars of the Internetthat is, freedom, participation, openness, and innovationare in danger.
Therefore, I believe it is necessary to protect the role of the Internet and, above all, the role that the Internet can play in boosting economic growth, but also to ensure opportunities for all.
I therefore hope that the Commission works towards the goal of a united Europe in Dubai, speaking with one voice.

Many are the controversial proposals presented at the negotiating table of the World Conference on International Telecommunications, in particular those that foresee changes to the governance of the Internet, which call into question network neutrality, with negative repercussions for consumers.
At risk is therefore the freedom of the Internet, or more precisely, the freedom of expression and data protection.
What some states have proposed would in fact allow a government to snoop not only on the communications of its own citizens, but also on data traversing its networks.

The step from here to the limitation of freedom of expression and censorship is extremely short, and therefore I believe it to be in contradiction with the fundamental principles of the European Union.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, I have expressed my support for the text presented by my colleague, and in particular, I agree with the rapporteur in emphasizing the crucial role played by national judges in the application of law within the Union.

I therefore deem it necessary to fully support the efforts of the European Union aimed at improving and coordinating training on jurisdiction for judicial and administrative authorities and legal professionals.
All sector initiatives should be intensified to fully realize the concept of a Union based on the rule of law.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, in recent years, the extraction of so-called unconventional hydrocarbons, including shale gas and oil, has brought about an unprecedented transformation in global energy markets.
Europe, in order to address this situation and reduce its dependence on hydrocarbon imports, will therefore need to rely on its potential reserves of gas and lignite.
In this regard, some Member States have already authorized shale gas exploration and are preparing for the extraction phase, should discoveries allow it.
In a context such as this, it becomes necessary to monitor the regulations concerning shale gas extraction within the borders of the Union, so that the effects of its extinction do not diminish.
Extractions, undoubtedly valid from an economic standpoint, pose environmental concerns due to the potential release of harmful substances into groundwater and the atmosphere.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, I believe that today's occasion should be used to speak objectively about Kazakhstan and the important agreement that the country is negotiating with the European Union.
Kazakhstan is a crucial country regarding the stability and strategic future of Central Asia and is undeniably an important economic and commercial part of the European Union.
This is a country that has already initiated a process of economic reforms and also a democratic process, but which still needs to commit greatly to bring these processes to full completion.

It is, however, a country that, with this goal in mind, persists in showing itself ready for new and stronger reforms, and I believe that this is precisely the task of the European Union to accompany them.

I am certain, therefore, that the signing of this enhanced agreement will allow for significant progress, as its approval will strengthen an already solid and productive relationship and ensure consistent assistance from the European Union.

I remain convinced, and I believe this should have been emphasized even further in the report we will vote on tomorrow, that the improvement of progress towards democracy and human rights must be accompanied by a renewed and open, constructive reciprocal commitment.

Our goal should not be to take a negative stance toward these and other countries due to the lack of immediate change; our goal must be to support these countries' efforts to achieve the objective of respecting human rights principles as well.

Mr. President, Madam Commissioner, esteemed colleagues, I would like to thank the rapporteurs for the reports we will vote on tomorrow. Just a brief comment on the issue of spinning, and I associate myself with what I heard tonight as a unanimous voice from all colleagues.
But I wanted to dwell on the Ferrera report, which I greet and for which I congratulate him.
I wanted to say that the former Common Fisheries Policy only contributed to widening the gap between the institutions regulating fishing and its true actors, that is, the fishermen.

Unfortunately, until now in Europe, the lack of a proper definition of artisanal fishing has disadvantaged those who have always understood fishing as an activity linked to the traditions of their place, their seas, and their cuisine.

Thus, the conviction grew that the approach taken by the European Commission was to standardize all fishing in Europe under large-scale industrial fishing, following only market logic and not listening to the reasons of thousands of fishermen who for a couple of

For decades, they have operated according to rules related to ecosystem conservation, with which I cannot but agree, but which have never preserved the work activities of the micro-economy of artisanal fishing.
This initiative report is a strong signal to the Commission, which can be translated into practical actions to the benefit of the fishing microeconomy.
The report, in fact, highlights a series of advantages in allocating a minimum sum to small-scale fishing from the European Fund.

It will be necessary to encourage projects with integrated solutions that benefit the coastal community as a whole. Furthermore, Commissioner, it will be indispensable to encourage young people's access to employment opportunities.

In this sector, we have discussed this issue several times in committee, because otherwise, the fishing industry will likely die not only due to the depletion of the seas and fish stocks, but also because young people are no longer entering this field.
This report provides an opportunity to include training and incentive initiatives for young people who wish to enter the sector.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, like many colleagues, today I ask the Council that made this proposal, but what do you want to do, ladies and gentlemen of Europe?
Do you want to minimize it, freeze it in the future?
But it is that same Europe which then seeks to be revitalized through Van Rompuy's document on integration.
But with what consistency, I ask, does Varro Poirier manage these two files?

And what consistency can citizens find between the decisions of July, employment and growth, the resounding calls for hope and the future in the European Union, which we also hear from the Council, and this violent fall, in the name of realism, into a minimal survival perspective?
How will it be possible, with these figures and these cuts, to translate the much-praised great reforms of cohesion and the CAP into concrete actions and active policies?
Here, these are sincere questions, we would like a clear, honest answer, because there are signs of institutional schizophrenia that Parliament no longer accepts, that citizens no longer accept.
The Parliament seeks consistency, it demands credibility.

The first criticism is that at the budget level, we are far off, let alone growth and investments, we are at the 2008 budget. It must be acknowledged, however, that regarding heading 1a, Van Rompuy's proposal reverses the scandalous Cypriot hypothesis.
It is true that here the role of the budget is recognized as an indispensable driver of growth in certain sectors, in addition to national budgets.

But let it be clear that both growth and innovation must not come at the expense of other sectors that are also part of growth and job creation, such as cohesion policy and, dear colleagues, agricultural policy as well. Agricultural policy has increased employment and is increasingly focused on innovation and territorial protection.

Our territory, growth and jobs, culture, education, transnational networks, the CEF, and also solidarity and international development, human rights worldwide, and our contribution to the Millennium Goals.

Before us, unfortunately, is the usual spectacle of the Council: no vision, no leadership, a Babel of competing and opposed national interests, an inextricable hatred of vetoes, expectations, and general discontent.
And Europe, unfortunately, is the great absentee.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, shark finning is an environmentally unacceptable practice, as it threatens the sustainability of certain shark species, which, from that perspective, are endangered.
Social and economic, as it involves the waste of a food product with commercial value, as well as from an ethical standpoint, as it demonstrates a complete lack of respect for animal life.

Although this practice has been banned since 2003 in European waters and for the European fleet, the Commission has decided to present a proposal aimed at eliminating the exemption to the prohibition on the removal of shark fins on board Union fishing vessels.

This proposal, in addition to further ensuring that sharks receive the protection they need, will thus enable the European Union to actively contribute to the ongoing global effort to eradicate the cruel practice of shark finning in other parts of the world.
